entry.title: The AI Stack Is Ready — Are You? The Challenge No Longer Is Technology
entry.content:
The Challenge No Longer Is Technology

Having worked hands-on with enterprise software for close to three decades, I’ve seen countless technology shifts — some promising incremental gains, others causing deep industry disruption. But none of them — none — have matured as quickly and as loudly as GenAI.

 

We are no longer in the “wait and see” phase. The stack is here. The APIs are mature. The building blocks — from LLMs to vector databases and orchestration frameworks — are all operational. There’s no question that we now have the technological backbone to deliver GenAI-enabled solutions across practically any business function.

Even common criticisms like hallucinations are being actively addressed. With test-time compute techniques — like prompt engineering, function calling, retrieval-augmented generation, and tool usage — hallucinations are kept at bay, quality radically increases, and results become not only reliable but robust. These advances prove a critical point: most GenAI objectives are technically attainable today.

Sure, the LLMs will continue to evolve, improving in reasoning and domain specialization. But they are already good enough to be effectively leveraged in real-world workflows — assuming the right usage patterns, guardrails, and integration strategies are in place.

So if tech is no longer the bottleneck… what is?

 

The Real Challenge: Ideas and Governance

Once upon a time, our hardest problem was figuring out how to make the tech work. Today, the hardest problem is figuring out what to build, how to deploy it responsibly, and how to scale and govern it across a rapidly shifting organizational landscape.

Think about it: spinning up a chatbot with retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) is no longer a moonshot. Hooking up a vector DB to your internal documents, embedding GenAI into Fiori apps or ABAP logic, orchestrating workflows with agentic logic — this is all doable. But what’s much harder is identifying high-value, sustainable use cases and creating a framework that doesn’t devolve into chaos as teams independently launch proof-of-concepts without strategy or alignment.

 

Why Ideation Matters More Than Ever

Let’s be honest: the biggest risk with GenAI today isn’t that the models don’t work — it’s that either we’re not building enough or we’re building too much, too fast, and too randomly. Every team spins up their own assistant. Use cases are vague. Nothing talks to each other. No reuse. No alignment. That’s not innovation — that’s chaos.

 

We’ve moved past the stage where the question is “Can we build this?”

Now it’s about “Should we build it?”

And even more importantly: “How do we keep it working well over time?”

 

This is why ideation can’t just be a sticky note exercise or a quick prompt storming session in ChatGPT. We have to treat it with the same rigor we apply to architecture. That means thinking about the business context, designing for scale, and planning for long-term sustainability — not just the MVP.

And here’s where the tough questions start to pop up — the ones we should be asking upfront:

  • Are we using the most effective language model from a quality vs. cost perspective?
  • Are we selecting the fastest possible model for latency-sensitive workflows? (If you’re doing multi-agent interactions, speed matters a lot.)
  • How is the quality of the responses behaving over time? Are we tracking degradation or drift?
  • What’s our strategy for testing newer LLMs as they come out? Should we switch? If so, how do we regression test across use cases without breaking things?
  • As our knowledge base grows, are we managing it properly? Is it staying focused, or are we bloating it with irrelevant context that just confuses the model?

These aren’t just technical questions. These are product and platform questions. And unless we ask them early — during ideation — we risk building solutions that are impressive in a demo but fragile, expensive, or completely unmaintainable in production.

Ideation today needs to account for all of this. It’s not just about dreaming big — it’s about designing smart.

 

Governance: From One-Off Demos to Scalable Systems

Without governance, GenAI becomes a set of disconnected experiments. With governance, it becomes an enabler of business-wide transformation.

This governance isn’t just about policies or committees. It’s about having:

  • Reusable components (tools, prompts, agents)
  • Common platforms (secured access to LLMs, retrievers, memory)
  • Evaluation metrics (accuracy, drift, hallucination tracking)
  • Ownership models (who builds, who maintains, who retrains)

 

Organizations that don’t invest here will be stuck in demo land. Those that do? They’ll build AI capabilities into their operational DNA — from support, finance, and HR to production and logistics.

 

FinOps: The Overlooked Layer of GenAI Operations

Another area that absolutely needs attention is FinOps — because GenAI might be easy to spin up, but it can get expensive fast.

Where are we spending the most? Are the solutions optimized from a cost perspective, or are we overpaying for high-end models when cheaper alternatives would do the job? And more importantly, how do we split the overall bill across different teams or functions using different LLM providers?

If multiple agents are running on different models — OpenAI for one workflow, Mistral or Claude for another — how do we assign those costs back to the right cost centers? Who’s consuming what? Are we operating in a user-payer model? Or is everything being lumped into a single invoice no one can untangle?

These questions need to be addressed before GenAI gets deeply embedded into everyday operations. Without visibility and accountability, you risk not only spiraling costs but also poor architectural decisions driven by unclear usage patterns.

FinOps isn’t just finance’s problem — it’s part of good governance.

 

The Role of Architects and Tech Leaders

This is where it gets personal for me.

As someone who’s been on the architecture side of SAP, building custom solutions for large enterprises, I see a massive opportunity — and responsibility. Our role as architects and tech leaders is evolving.

We’re not just evaluating frameworks and drawing diagrams anymore. We’re setting the tone for AI readiness. We’re defining guardrails, pushing for smart reusability, and fostering the right kind of innovation — not the “one demo per team” variety, but the kind that results in sustainable business improvement.

 

So… Are You Ready

You don’t need to wait for the perfect model or the next framework release. The AI stack is ready. The frontier now is not technical — it’s organizational.

  • If you’re a builder: build with intent.
  • If you’re a strategist: align use cases with value.
  • If you’re a leader: create clarity and structure.

Because in the GenAI era, the best ideas — not the best tech — will win.

entry.title: Include released successor objects from "cloudification repo" in your ABAP custom code migration
entry.content:
Many SAP customers are currently in the phase of migrating their SAP ERP systems to S/4HANA. For those who choose a brownfield or bluefield approach the old ERP system is converted and the customers extensions and own applications (Z* objects) become part of the new system.

Then, the process of Custom Code Adaptation kicks in where the ERP functionality is analyzed and corrected in a way that the objects run again in S/4HANA. See https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/get-started-with-the-abap-custom-code-migration-process/bc-p/14049622 or https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-s-4hana-system-conversion-custom-code-adaptation-process/ba-p/13337309 for more details.

The custom code correction process can be time consuming and challenging depending on the size and complexity of the original ERP system. A big part of the custom code objects will be touched. The basis for the checks and corrections is the ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) with the check variant for S/4HANA (e.g. S4HANA_READINESS_2023).

In case the customer wants to move functionality to SAP BTP ABAP or the S/4HANA (public) Cloud versions it is not sufficient to make the old ERP code just S/4HANA ready. The cloud versions have a heavily restricted set of the ABAP language (so called language version 5 ) and furthermore access to SAP standard objects is allowed to (relatively few) released objects only. For instance, you must not use the MARA table to read materials but the I_PRODUCT CDS. This information is stored in the so called cloudification repository (https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/how-to-check-your-custom-code-for-abap-cloud/ba-p/13567124 ) which is regularly updated. (See https://github.com/SAP/abap-atc-cr-cv-s4hc for the Raw data).

It contains as well successor information for some of the old ERP objects in particular for the data base tables which makes it particularly interesting for the custom code migration process. See note https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/3284711 for installation of the according ATC check / check "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)"  in releases before 2023 FP 3.

The idea is now to use the officially released successors for the objects which need to be corrected anyway during the migration ERP -> S/4HANA.

A (simple) example: When accessing table SKA1 corrections could be necessary because of the new account type attributes e.g. GLACCOUNT_TYPE in S/4; secondary cost elements are saved now as well. This is found by the S4HANA_READINESS_2023. The same access is found by the "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)" check as well:

The solution to solve both issues is to check if secondary cost elements are concerned and to follow the recommendation in the finding. In the correction the successor object (DDLS I_GLACCOUNTINCHARTOFACCOUNTS) should be used directly:

 

This combination approach makes a part of the own developments "cloud ready" and "S/4HANA ready" at the same time without a big additional effort. And anyway, it is better for upgrade stability to use officially released objects!

Here are 3 possible approaches to achieve this:

Approach 1: Out of the box: Combined Check

Create a Z ATC Check variant and select the checks from S4HANA_READINESS* and the check "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)" . The easiest would be to copy S4HANA_READINESS* and then to select in the maintenance of the check variants (via transaction /nSCI):

 

 

Once you run the check you will see the result as in this example:

 

The findings from the combined check contain already all needed information but there are two shortcomings: the list contains many irrelevant entries; not all check categories (only when the successor is defined) nor all findings are relevant in the context of S/4HANA custom code adoption (e.g. Successor I_COUNTRY for T005 table doesn’t solve a Custom Code Migration issue).

Approach 2: Add information from Cloudification Repo manually

Instead of a combined check variant the successor information could be added via Excel / VLOOKUP (SVERWEIS in German) as well using these steps:

  1. Run the standard ATC check for Custom Code Analysis (e.g. S4HANA_READINESS_2023)
  2. Download the detailed list from ATC to Excel (include in any case the field reference object / Referenzobjekt)
  3. Download the cloudification repo from here https://github.com/SAP/abap-atc-cr-cv-s4hc/blob/main/src/objectReleaseInfoLatest.csv
  4. Open the data in Excel and copy the sheet to your original excel in a new tab
  5. Add a new column to the first tab from ATC data and combine the data via VLOOKUP: find a possible successor objects in the released objects for the reference objects

A possible result could look like this:

 

I added an example excel for convenience reasons to Github here: https://github.com/Lutzi3/cloud_mig_atc/blob/main/ATC_S4HANA_CLOUDIF_REPO_EXAMPLE.xlsx 

Then, when processing the ATC findings, the successor objects from Excel can be used directly in the corrections.

Approach 3: Using a custom enhancement to the SAP ATC S/4HANA: Released objects as additional information

In order to avoid the manual Excel steps and to have a lean combined list of the relevant findings only there is also the possibility to enhance the "additional information" section via an implicit enhancement or via another copy of the standard check classes in the S/4HANA Custom Code area. If you decide for the enhancement you can use the methode GET_DETAIL_FROM_DATA_BUFFER  from the central utility class CL_CI_S4H_COMMON and add the successor object information there.

The result is that if there is the successor object available it will be put to the Additional Information Section of the findings as shows the following  example:

 

 

There is an example version on Github for this as well: https://github.com/Lutzi3/cloud_mig_atc 

Now the existing ATC S4HANA readiness check is enhanced by the new released object information such as that you can directly correct the old ERP object reference and replace it by the latest officially released SAP cloud ready object!

entry.title: SAP HANA PARAMETERS TUNING FOR PERFORMANCE OPTIMIZATION
entry.content:
I am writing this blog for publishing on the SAP Community, focused on SAP HANA Performance Optimization. It's structured to be informative, experience-driven, and valuable to a technical audience.

SAP HANA is known for its lightning-fast in-memory computing power, but like any high-performance engine, it requires Parameters tuning, Maintenance, and optimization to ensure it's running at its peak. Whether you're an SAP Basis Consultant, HANA Admin, or someone involved in performance analysis, this guide will walk you through proven techniques and practical tips that have worked in real-world SAP projects. HANA Parameters Tuning required in case of Migration, Implementation Projects as well as Support AMS Project.

When we are migrated to SAP HANA or Installing New Hana Database, all parameters are default parameters which may not perform as per your requirement or as per your landscape So we need to tune those parameters for system performance. SAP HANA parameter tuning for performance optimization involves configuring various system settings to maximize efficiency. Key areas include data modeling, load optimization, query optimization, and utilizing features like partitioning and columnar storage. Fine-tuning these parameters can significantly impact data processing speed, memory usage, and overall system responsiveness

Why HANA Performance Optimization Matters ?

In an enterprise environment, poor performance can impact business processes, reporting speed, and even downstream applications. Optimizing HANA ensures:

  • Faster analytics and reporting
  • Better end-user experience
  • Reduced infrastructure costs
  • Longer hardware lifecycle

 SAP S/4HANA End-to-End Performance Overview

SAP S/4HANA Architecture consist of 3-tiers, a SAP Fiori UI5 frontend, an SAP S/4HANA ABAP backend and a SAP HANA database

Database and ABAP processing times are two primary components of ABAP response time. Effects of pushing code to SAP HANA changes standard metrics of ABAP and database time as well as the common SAP R/3  and S/4 standard of 1 second per Dialog step.

Some SAP HANA features and ABAP coding that contribute to backend response times.

  • Core Data Services (CDS)
  • ABAP Managed Database Procedures
  • Compatibility views
  • Parallel processing in SAP HANA
  • Columnar in-memory database

End-to-End performance of an SAP S/4HANA system is spread across 4 layers: SAP Fiori UI, SAP S/4HANA  ABAP layer, CDS views and SAP HANA

Below are 11 Points need to perform for HANA Performance Optimization.

1. Monitor Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)

Start with regular monitoring of essential KPIs:

Metric

Tool/Transaction

What to Look For

Memory Usage

HANA Studio, HDB Admin, ST06

High memory without releases

CPU Utilization

top, vmstat, ST06

CPU consistently >85%

iostat, HANA Cockpit

Spikes during peak load

Expensive Statements

ST03N, ST05, SQL Plan Cache

Long-running or unoptimized SQLs

Delta Merge Status

M_DELTA_MERGE_STATISTICS

High frequency or failing merges

2. Use the HANA Cockpit and HANA Studio Wisely

Both tools provide dashboards to analyze:

  • Memory load and footprint
  • Active sessions and threads
  • Expensive SQL statements
  • Alerts (CPU, Disk, Memory, column unloads)

Tip: Configure alerting thresholds to get notified before performance degrades.

3. Data Volume Management (DVM)

Large tables or outdated data can slow down performance.

  • Archive or purge old data
  • Split large tables into partitions
  • Use RSDA_DATA_SELECT or DBACOCKPIT to find large table

Optional Tools for Automation

Full and delta backups configured and validated

5. Best practice configuration checks for SAP HANA.

Run the HANA_Configuration_Parameters_1.00.90+ or HANA_Configuration_Parameters_2.00.040+.txt script, which is maintained in SAP note 1969700 SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA (below is a sample output) , Do Mini Checks in System and check all parameters and set SAP recommended parameters accordingly.

Additional Info

  • These checks can be executed on the SYSTEMDB and on each Tenant DB (for Hana 2.0) - but are particularly important for the Tenant DB's
  • Each Tenant DB can have different parameter values set, depending on each customer requirement
  • It is recommended that each Tenant has these best practice parameter values in place before productive use starts i.e. run these checks immediately after installation or upgrade, implement parameter value recommendations and test that these meet your business requirements
  • The output of the script will only show Hana parameters which are not currently set as per best practice recommendations
  • It will give recommended parameter value settings and note references on the particular parameter/topic area
  • In the P (Priority) column, you can see the most critical parameters to be set - 1 has highest priority
  • It will give actual SQL commands (ALTER statements) to set the parameter to the required value
  • And also an UNDO_COMMAND should you need to revert the parameter
  • If opening a support case with SAP Technical Support, providing the output of this parameter check will help to speed up the analysis
  • Check out the SAP HANA Configuration Parameter Reference: Index guide as per your HANA revision
  • In List SAP also provides Commands to modify Parameters. Just need to run those commands at SQL in HANA Cockpit or Studio.

7. OS and Infrastructure Checks

  • Ensure proper NUMA configuration
  • Keep kernel and firmware updated
  • Use SSDs for /hana/data and /hana/log
  • Monitor swap usage: HANA hates swapping!

8. List of Parameters Tuning at SAP Application Level

Recommended Value

 9. Smart Delta Merge Strategy

Delta merges can cause spikes in memory and CPU.

  • Check M_DELTA_MERGE_STATISTICS regularly
  • Avoid frequent merges on volatile tables
  • Automate delta merge scheduling for off-peak times

Tip: Always back up config and consult SAP notes before changing parameters.

To keep control of the delta merge we keep our table enable AUTOMERGE but in the data loading time we keep it into disable auto merge and enable smart merge for large volume tables.

Auto Merge :  HANA keeps a compressed “main” store of column tables and an uncompressed “delta” store, for new items. Periodically, a process called mergedog combines the two in a DELTA MERGE process. Sometimes however your tables may not be configured to automerge (you can issue ALTER TABLE table name ENABLE AUTOMERGE), and occasionally merged fails and you have to restart HANA. This can cause the delta store to become very large, and because it is uncompressed, this is a big issue if you don’t have much RAM.

Below Command:-

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ALTER TABLE “SCHEMA”.”TABLE” DISABLE AUTOMERGE;

IMPORT FROM ‘/sapmnt/log/test.ctl’ WITH THREADS 120 BATCH 200000;

MERGE DELTA OF “SCHEMA”.”TABLE”;

ALTER TABLE “SCHEMA”.”TABLE ENABLE AUTOMERGE;

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

10. Use SAP Recommendations & Notes.

SAP regularly publishes SAP HANA performance-related notes. Some helpful ones include:

  • SAP Note 1999997 – SAP HANA Troubleshooting Guide (FAQ: SAP HANA Memory)
  • SAP Note 2399079 – Elimination of hdbparam in HANA 2
  • SAP Note 2186744 FAQ: SAP HANA Parameters.
  • SAP Note 2600030 Parameter Recommendations in SAP HANA Environments
  •  SAP Note 1969700 - SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA - (For Mini Checks),
  • SAP HANA Troubleshooting and Performance Analysis Guide for your SAP HANA Platform revision at https://help.sap.com/viewer/p/SAP_HANA_PLATFORM

 11. Periodic Housekeeping

  • Clean up old logs and trace files.
  • Reclaim memory, data volume and logs (ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM LOGS, MEMORY, DATAVOLUME)
  • Remove obsolete backups from disk

 Conclusion

SAP HANA is a powerful platform, but like any high-performance machine, it needs care and attention. By combining smart monitoring, regular analysis, and data management best practices, you can keep your system running efficiently and support your business-critical operations smoothly.

entry.title: Currency Changeover needs on productive SAP S/4 HANA On-Prem and Private Cloud Environment
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog outlines the typical business triggers that drive the need for a currency changeover in a productive SAP S/4HANA environment. It also highlights the possible realization methodology to support such transformations.

General Business Triggers

Currency conversion requirements are usually driven by strategic, regulatory, or compliance-related events that necessitate a change in the currency model of your SAP system. These scenarios often arise during financial transformations, mergers, organizational restructurings, or statutory reporting changes. Common business triggers include:

  • Legal Currency Change in a Country: A country may mandate a change in its local currency due to reasons such as joining a monetary union (e.g., adoption of the Euro), experiencing hyperinflation, or undergoing political or economic reform.
  • Extension of Reporting Currency: The current ERP system may be configured for only one local reporting currency. Due to requirements such as hyperinflation, currency instability, or IFRS reporting, businesses may need to enable an additional parallel local currency in their productive environment.
  • Group Currency Alignment for Global Operations: Companies operating across multiple countries under different subsidiaries may need to establish a unified group reporting currency to align financial reporting across application modules.
  • Change in Corporate Headquarters/ Group Structure/ Merger & Acquisition: A shift in the corporate headquarters or the inclusion of a new entity with a different group currency may require changes to the existing group currency setup for consolidated financial reporting.
  • Parallel Valuation of Inventories in different valuation methods: Organizations may need to enable transfer pricing and support parallel inventory valuations to gain financial insights from different valuation perspectives and meet reporting requirements.

Possible Scenarios of Currency Changeovers in SAP S/4HANA System

Currency changeover requirements in an SAP S/4HANA system can arise in various business scenarios depending on the reporting, legal, or strategic needs. Below are some common scenarios with illustrative examples:

Scenario 1: Change of First Local Currency Across All Company Codes

A requirement to change the primary local currency (currency type 10) consistently in a company code using a fixed exchange rate.

  • Example: Company code 1000 is currently using INR as the first local currency. The requirement is to change it to USD.

Scenario 2: Introduction of a Parallel Currency with Valuation View

Business requires an additional parallel currency integrated across FI and ML, associated with a specific valuation view (e.g., 11, 12, 31, or 32) to support group or profit center valuation.

  • Example: For company code 1000, there is a need to introduce Group Currency in Group Valuation as a parallel valuation view.

Scenario 3: Introduction of a Freely Definable Currency

The need to add a freely definable currency within the FI application module to support additional parallel reporting.

Refer to SAP Note 2334583 – Introduction of new currencies / currency types in SAP S/4HANA, which describes how to manage new currencies via the Manage Currencies Cockpit.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the requirement is to introduce a freely defined currency for additional reporting.

Scenario 4: Changeover of Group Currency (Client Currency)

Changing the Group Currency (currency type 30) across the system consistently—for example, from EUR to USD. This may involve replacement across all application modules, such as FI, CO, and ML, where group currency is already in use.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the group currency needs to be changed from USD to EUR.

Scenario 5: Introduction of Group Currency in Systems Without Prior Usage

In systems where Group Currency was not used historically—such as ECC systems using CO currency types 10/20—the migration to S/4HANA may result in the CO currency (now known as "Global Currency" - Refer SAP note 2344012 - Currencies in Universal Journal) occupying the KSL field group in the ACDOCA table. Introducing group currency in such a case requires consistent integration across all modules, including FI and CO, and overwriting existing KSL values where necessary.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the requirement is to introduce Group Currency as both the Controlling Area Currency and an FI-integrated currency (BSEG level).

Scenario 6: Organizational restructure (change Controlling area currency)

Organizational Restructuring such as a merging multiple controlling areas into a single, unified structure to support centralized management may require the alignment of controlling area currencies to ensure consistency across the organizational hierarchy.

Example: There are 3 Controlling Areas 1000, 2000, 3000 with varying currency settings. Requirement is to merge the controlling areas 1000 and 2000 into 3000.

 Scenario 7: Activation of Universal Parallel Accounting (UPA):
To comply with multiple accounting standards, organizations may seek to activate Universal Parallel Accounting, which requires alignment of existing currency configurations and pre-requisites.

Example: For company code 1000, 0L and 1L ledger is active with company code currency (LC1) and group currency (LC2) and a freely defined currency. Requirement is to activate business function UPA and align the currencies and ledger across application module -FI, FI-AA and ML.

Realization Methodology

Once a company code is productive or live with transactional data, changing the configured currency must not be performed by simply transporting the modified configuration. Moving configuration changes without transforming the already posted documents can lead to data inconsistencies in the live system, potentially causing critical disruptions in business processes—such as clearing open invoices.

To make changes in currency settings, both the configuration and the associated transactional data must be transformed. For transforming existing posted documents, the SAP DMLT Currency Conversion Service is required. For more information, refer to the Currency Conversion Solution Brief.

Such data transformations in a live production system demand a highly precise and controlled changeover, ensuring consistency at the database level and seamless continuity of SAP software operations. Therefore, every relevant business scenario should be carefully reviewed in the system, considering current configurations and customizations across all connected application modules.

SAP DMLT offers a technical feasibility study to outline system data dependencies and prerequisite conditions. This is followed by a detailed customer workshop. The realization of the transformation requirement is delivered under a separate professional consulting contract and executed as a project.

The overall delivery process is broadly divided into two parts:

1. Pre-Qualification of Requirement

It is essential to pre-qualify the business requirement to ensure the right-fit transformation solution is offered. This starts with gathering preliminary details about the business requirement and application usage within the system through a technical questionnaire, available at Data Unification & Harmonization.

Based on the responses, SAP can propose a feasibility study to assess the system, evaluate overall complexity, and deliver a detailed proposal. This assessment typically takes around two weeks, including the deployment of analysis tools in the system.

An SAP solution expert will perform the system assessment and present the key insights during a customer workshop session. This is followed by the provision of commercial details through the regional SAP Market Unit.

2. Project Delivery

Depending on the complexity of the engagement, the required number of mock execution cycles will be determined during the scoping phase. In general, data transformation projects of this nature involve a minimum of three mock cycles before the production data cutover. The purpose of a mock execution is to simulate the complete production data conversion, validate the results, and estimate the overall downtime required for the production system. Each mock execution cycle includes several phases, which can be broadly classified as follows:

2.1 Technical Preparation Phase of Add-On (Uptime):

These types of transformation capabilities are deployed into the customer system as a separate add-on, delivered as transportable content. The mock execution system should be a recent copy of the production system, with hardware configuration closely matching that of the production environment. Once the tool content is deployed, the technical preparation phase begins, during which SAP DMLT experts prepare the transformation tool. This phase typically takes 2–3 weeks and includes uptime activities and the generation of technical programs for the relevant table-fields.

2.2 Data Conversion Phase (Downtime):

After the uptime preparatory activities are completed, the agreed business downtime begins. During this period, currency conversion is performed directly at the database table-field level. All relevant currency values (currency key/amount) are updated in the respective parallel currency fields in affected application areas (e.g., FI-GL, FI-AA, ML, CO etc) using a fixed exchange rate. Such conversions are applied retroactively for all fiscal years and Go-Live is not bound by a key date.

2.3 Post-Conversion Data Reconciliation Phase (Downtime):

Currency conversion may result in rounding differences, especially in accounting areas where specific rules apply—such as clearings that must net to zero. It is generally recommended to ignore rounding differences from previous fiscal years and reconcile only the current fiscal year. For business continuity, reconciliation of current fiscal year data is performed immediately after the conversion to mitigate the impact of rounding differences and to synchronize data across tightly integrated modules such as FI, CO, and ML.

2.4 Post-Processing Testing Phase (Downtime):

Once the reconciliation phase is complete, the transformed system is handed over to the customer’s IT/application team for a sanity check during downtime. Upon successful completion of the sanity check, the transformed system is reopened for normal business operations.

How to Engage with SAP

If your business requirement involves transforming any currency-related aspect in a live, productive SAP S/4HANA system, you should engage with the SAP Data Management and Landscape Transformation (DMLT) consulting team.

There are two primary ways to initiate the engagement:

  1. Create a Support Incident
    Submit an incident via the SAP ONE Support Launchpad under the component:
    CA-LT-SRV (Landscape Transformation Services)
  2. Contact via Email
    Reach out directly to the DMLT Global Consulting Experts by emailing-  sap_dmlt_gce@sap.com

The SAP DMLT team will guide you through the pre-assessment process, feasibility evaluation, and project-based service engagement tailored to your specific system and transformation needs.

Reference SAP OSS Notes:

3476589 - Parallel Currency Transformations in S/4HANA

481938 - System Landscape Optimization Services

3229024 - S/4HANA Local Currency Changeover - Central Note

3334743 - S/4HANA / SFIN 720/730: Is a subsequent implementation and activation of a Profit Center Valuation and/or Group valuation possible?

2882025 - Multiple valuation approaches/transfer prices in SAP S/4HANA, on-premise edition

175758 - Deactivating transfer prices/multiple valuation approaches

Other References:

Blog Post: DMLT- Currency Conversion Services Overview and Insights

Currencies Managed in Parallel in the Universal Journal | SAP Help Portal

Disclaimer: This blog is intended only for knowledge sharing about currency conversion service on SAP S/4 HANA which might help customer in their landscape transformation requirements. It should not be considered as guideline for performing such transformation services on their own in the SAP landscape. Any data transformation efforts should be thoroughly assessed in consultation with qualified subject matter experts, supported by a comprehensive system study, and aligned with the appropriate approvals from your auditors.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Control Tower: Q2 2025 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the first half of 2025, global sustainability governance has entered a new phase of scrutiny and recalibration. The EU Omnibus amendments to the CSRD have postponed timelines and reduced the scope of immediate obligations for thousands of companies, temporarily easing the pressure of compliance. However, this regulatory pause has only sharpened the spotlight on data integrity, preparedness, and strategic ESG integration. 

At the same time, investors, regulators, and civil society are intensifying their expectations. Public disclosures are no longer judged on completeness alone—they must be audit-ready, aligned with recognized frameworks like ESRS and EU Taxonomy. Companies are expected to move beyond box-ticking compliance into continuous ESG performance management, proactively steering their sustainability journey. 

SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) is designed precisely for this challenge. It enables organizations to: 

  • Record ESG factors with out-of-the-box integration to SAP systems and trusted third-party sources 
  • Analyze performance across financial, operational, and sustainability dimensions to support informed decisions 
  • Accelerate the transition through auditable, framework-aligned reporting—covering both regulatory and voluntary disclosures, powered by AI 

Building on our momentum from Q1, this quarter's updates focus on strengthening ESRS-aligned metric coverage, deeper analytical flexibility, improved auditability, and tighter alignment with financial structures. 

 

Expansion of SAP-provided metric coverage   

To support organizations on their ESRS compliance journey, SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) continues to expand its library of SAP-provided metrics aligned with the European Sustainability Reporting Standards. These include both qualitative and quantitative definitions based on EFRAG's implementation guidance. Current metric coverage is available in the SAP Help Portal and detailed in the SAP Community blog, offering transparency and reuse for accelerated implementation.  

 

Looking ahead, we plan to reach approximately 80% coverage of ESRS data points by the end of 2025, including metrics from ESRS 2, S2–S4, G1, and additional quantitative metrics from ESRS Topical Standards. This roadmap aims to enable our customers to progressively adopt SCT content for structured, auditable, and regulation-ready ESG disclosures while maintaining flexibility to extend for sector-specific or company-specific needs. 

 

Analyze ESG Data App Enhancements 

The Analyze ESG Data application now offers a significantly improved analytics experience with the introduction of the Analytics tab. Users can explore all standard custom quantitative metrics in greater depth by applying drill-down dimensions, choosing between chart or table formats, and configuring default views tailored to reporting needs. This new flexibility allows up to three charts to be displayed simultaneously, each with independent metric, period, and structure settings. 

In parallel, users can manage and switch between saved configurations of grouped metric tiles (“Overviews”), enabling different perspectives for different stakeholders or strategic priorities. Together, these enhancements empower users to personalize and streamline how ESG data is analyzed, viewed, and shared – supporting more informed decision-making and stronger alignment with sustainability goals. Find full details here: Using the Analyze ESG Data Application.

 

Custom Templates for “Generate ESG Reports with AI” App 

The Generate ESG Reports with AI app now offers greater flexibility and control through the introduction of custom templates. Users can create or edit templates to tailor the structure and content of ESG reports using available SAP-provided quantitative metrics.  

Within the Templates section, you can now select “Create” to build a new template or modify an existing one by adding sections and subsections, defining narrative text, and selecting from a predefined list of charts and tables. For each component, a content preview is available to ensure alignment with the selected reporting period. Once finalized, templates can be saved and reused, enabling consistent and structured ESG reporting across time periods.  

When generating a report, you can preview or download the result as a PDF—and for added customization, you can edit any section manually. SAP's built-in AI-assistance now supports dynamic revisions: simply select a passage and use the “Revise” option to receive suggestions to shorten or lengthen the text, helping refine your final ESG narrative with ease and speed. 

 

Fiscal Period Support 

The new Manage Fiscal Year Variants app brings flexible fiscal period support to SAP Sustainability Control Tower, allowing customers to define and activate custom fiscal year variants that align with their internal planning cycles. Whether using standard calendar months or granular date-based periods (like semi-monthly ranges), organizations can now tailor their ESG data analysis and reporting across key apps such as Analyze ESG Data, Manage GHG Data, and View Emission Dashboard. Built-in validation checks help ensure data compatibility, with options to consolidate or reimport data when switching to a new variant. This enables more accurate reporting, tighter alignment with financial periods, and greater control over how sustainability data is structured and interpreted across the organization. 

 

Change log updates 

In Q2, we've significantly improved transparency and traceability across SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT). Users can now track create, update, and delete changes to public overview configurations in the Analyze ESG Data app using the View Change Logs app. This functionality extends further, providing detailed logs for changes in business activity data, clearly showing the number of updated or imported records and distinguishing between actual and target data. 

 

New Languages Supported 

To better serve global enterprises, SAP SCT now supports Turkish and Italian languages. This update enables local teams to work in their native languages and enhances cross-regional collaboration on sustainability data collection and reporting. 

 

H2 2025 Roadmap Updates 

Looking ahead, we’re focused on simplifying and harmonizing ESG data consumption and reporting. A key milestone will be the delivery of a unified Read API for metric values – supporting both quantitative and qualitative data – to  make calculated ESG metrics easily accessible to external tools like disclosure management platforms. This API will also expose key metadata (including ESG standard references) and allow for both bulk and individual metric retrieval based on reporting scopes. We’re also working on improving flexibility in data modeling by enabling custom account groups, account-to-group mappings, and supporting activity data input through multiple channels. Additionally, we’ll continue expanding metric-level analysis, measure drilldowns, and export formats in the Analyze ESG data application. To enhance data quality and reporting alignment, we’re introducing tools for guiding data requirements based on double materiality, setting up reporting hierarchies and data sources, and improving transparency on data completeness. In parallel, we aim to deliver ESRS-aligned metric definitions that cover up to 70% of EFRAG's guidance, along with clear documentation and community updates to keep you informed as mentioned above. Stay tuned: SCT Roadmap Explorer. 

 

Additional Information 

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Control Tower, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

entry.title: SAP Green Token H1-25 Updates & Highlights: Raising the Bar on Sustainability Compliance
entry.content:
As sustainability regulations tighten, and global supply chains grow more complex,  SAP Green Token    continues to deliver pragmatic solutions for chain-of-custody, compliance, and operational clarity. Our H1 2025 release focuses on deepening support for the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR)

 

Making EUDR Work for Complex Supply Chains

SAP Green Token  delivers extended support for Article 9 of the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR), covering both operator and trader personas—from inbound geolocation capture to DDS number generation and outbound data transfer

We built these capabilities for enterprise complexity. Whether managing dozens of sites, importing from outside the EU, or reducing supplier risk, Green Token simplifies compliance and provides a future-ready foundation.

✅Highlights from the H1 release:

  • Operator & Trader support: DDS generation, handling EU and non-EU suppliers, TRACES integration
  • Transactional-level reporting: Built on ERP data, avoids duplication, reduces risk
  • Open API integrations: Import GeoJSON and DDS data from portals, GR processes, or external systems

Figure 1: All end-to-end scenarios covered in SAP Green Token in H1

🔄Supporting Article 9 Workflows for the EU and Beyond

Global supply chains rarely follow a single linear flow. Most large enterprises manage multiple flows in parallel—across sites, regions, and regulatory jurisdictions. SAP Green Token is designed to handle exactly that.

We support inbound and outbound flow combinations under the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) including movements between EU and non-EU regions and across internal company sites. This enables companies to track, validate, and document material origin and DDS data across their full supply network—regardless of geography or supply chain complexity.

📥Built-In TRACES Integration
Green Token is directly connected to the EU TRACES system, enabling automated submission and tracking of DDS for both inbound and outbound shipments.

Based on your role (operator or trader), and the material flow direction, Green Token intelligently determines when to trigger TRACES submissions—minimizing errors, delays, and manual work. Simulation mode is also available for safe testing before go-live.

Why Transactional Reporting Matters

Most companies rely on annual reporting to track sustainability data—an approach still allowed under the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR). However, annual summaries can introduce risks, including outdated data, limited traceability, and delayed issue detection.

SAP Green Token offers an alternative: transactional-level reporting, seamlessly integrated with your ERP. This approach captures data per shipment, enabling real-time traceability, smarter DDS volume management, and proactive compliance.

✅Benefits:

  • More control: Filter by supplier, origin, or shipment quality
  • Risk isolation: One bad shipment won’t impact the entire batch
  • Smarter volume use: Avoid early DDS exhaustion
  • Lower long-term cost: Minimize corrections, fines, and rework

 

🎯Our Focus: Article 9, Done Exceptionally Well

SAP Green Token is purpose-built to support Article 9 of the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR)—the most operationally complex and compliance-critical part of the regulation. Our solution is designed to handle the transactional- and geolocation-level data management, organization, and submission required of operators and traders at scale.

Green Token provides deep SAP integration, automated DDS management, TRACES submission, and audit-ready traceability, all optimized for ERP-driven supply chains.

🧩 We also leave white space for partners to extend the platform. For example, NTT Data independently built a supplier data management extension on top of Green Token for a customer—and we’re now exploring how to scale that model across the ecosystem.

This modular and integration-friendly approach enables customers and partners to build what's right for their workflows—without adding cost or complexity where it's not needed.

 

Enablement & Go-To-Market Assets: Everything You Need to Succeed

We released a full library of go-to-market and training assets to help teams implement Green Token.

Highlights include:

  • ISCC and EUDR demo systems
  • FAQs, L2 decks, pricing guides, onboarding content
  • Bi-monthly training sessions via Partner Portal
  • Integration & API guides

 

What’s Coming Next?

In H2 2025, we’re expanding into a completely new use case with support for the EU Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), marking Green Token’s first step into carbon-related compliance. We’ll also continue to strengthen our EUDR offering to support evolving regulatory and customer needs.

Curious how we’re tackling CBAM? Explore our first wave of materials here:

  • 📄The 6 things every CFO should do to prepare for CBAM — Thought leadership article by Gunther Rothermel on CFO.com
  • 🌐What is EU CBAM? — A quick-read content hub that answers key questions and explains SAP’s role
  • 🎥Watch now: CBAM Declarant Reporting with SAP Green Token – our new video walkthrough of how the solution supports CBAM compliance 

 

Stay in Touch

We’re committed to delivering solutions that solve real problems—and we want to hear from you.

  • Submit feedback via the SAP Influence Portal
  • Request a demo via your SAP representative
  • Follow me on SAP Community

entry.title: A Step-by-Step Guide to Implementing an Excel Upload Button in a Fiori App using RAP
entry.content:
Live Demo

Here is a short video demonstrating the final Excel upload functionality in action.

 

For this demonstration, I've built a simple RAP application with a V4 UI. The application features an "Employee" table with three fields. The base of the application was created using the RAP generator, and I've also included early numbering logic for the Employee ID.

Step 1: Create a Fiori Project

To begin, create a new SAP Fiori project using the List Report template. This will serve as the foundation for our application.

Step 2: Add a Custom Button

With the project set up, the next step is to add a custom button. You can do this by using the open guided development feature. From there, choose the option to Add a Custom Action to a Page Using Extensions. Follow the prompts in the guide to insert the necessary code snippets for the "Excel Upload" button.

 

 

or 

Step 2: Configure the manifest.json File

The manifest.json file is the application descriptor, defining its structure, data sources, and routing. To add the "Excel Upload" button, you need to modify this file to define a custom action and extend the standard List Report controller with our custom logic.

You can either use the "Add a Custom Action to a Page Using Extensions" option in the guided development tool or update the manifest.json file directly with the following configuration. Pay close attention to the controlConfiguration and extends sections, which are key to enabling this functionality.

{
  "_version": "1.53.0",
  "sap.app": {
    "id": "uploadempexcel",
    "type": "application",
    "i18n": "i18n/i18n.properties",
    "applicationVersion": {
      "version": "0.0.1"
    },
    "title": "{{appTitle}}",
    "description": "{{appDescription}}",
    "resources": "resources.json",
    "sourceTemplate": {
      "id": "@sap/generator-fiori:lrop",
      "version": "1.18.2",
      "toolsId": "f8a70d19-c3d7-40bf-9b4b-03ba34f86143"
    },
    "dataSources": {
      "mainService": {
        "uri": "/sap/opu/odata4/sap/zui_upload_emp_o4/srvd/sap/zui_upload_emp_o4/0001/",
        "type": "OData",
        "settings": {
          "annotations": ["annotation"],
          "localUri": "localService/mainService/metadata.xml",
          "odataVersion": "4.0"
        }
      }
    }
  },
  "sap.ui5": {
    "flexEnabled": true,
    "dependencies": {
      "minUI5Version": "1.114.9",
      "libs": {
        "sap.m": {},
        "sap.ui.core": {},
        "sap.fe.templates": {}
      }
    },
    "routing": {
      "routes": [
        {
          "pattern": ":?query:",
          "name": "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList",
          "target": "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList"
        }
      ],
      "targets": {
        "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList": {
          "type": "Component",
          "id": "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList",
          "name": "sap.fe.templates.ListReport",
          "options": {
            "settings": {
              "contextPath": "/ZC_UPLOAD_EMP",
              "controlConfiguration": {
                "@com.sap.vocabularies.UI.v1.LineItem": {
                  "actions": {
                    "uploadExcelController.controller": {
                      "press": ".extension.uploadempexcel.ext.controller.uploadExcelController.uploadExcel",
                      "visible": true,
                      "enabled": true,
                      "requiresSelection": false,
                      "text": "Upload Excel"
                    }
                  }
                }
              }
            }
          }
        }
      }
    },
    "extends": {
      "extensions": {
        "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
          "sap.fe.templates.ListReport.ListReportController": {
            "controllerName": "uploadempexcel.ext.controller.uploadExcelController"
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Step 3: Create a Fragment for the Pop-up Screen

You'll need to create a fragment in the ext folder. This fragment will define the pop-up screen that appears when a user clicks the "Excel Upload" button.

 

<core:FragmentDefinition xmlns="sap.m" xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" xmlns:upload="sap.m.upload">
    <Dialog id="uploadDialogSet" title="Excel Upload">
        <content>
            <upload:UploadSet
                id="uploadSet"
                maxFileNameLength="200"
                fileTypes="xlsx, xls"
                afterItemAdded=".onAfterItemAdded"
                afterItemRemoved=".onAfterItemRemoved"
                uploadEnabled="true"
                />
        </content>
        <!-- CORRECTED: Changed from <buttons> to <beginButton> and <endButton> -->
        <beginButton>
            <Button id="idUploadB" text="Upload" press=".onUploadPress" type="Emphasized" enabled="false"/>
        </beginButton>
        <endButton>
            <Button id="idCancelB" text="Cancel" press=".onCloseDialog" />
        </endButton>
    </Dialog>
</core:FragmentDefinition>

Step 4: Implement the Controller Logic

The main logic for handling the file upload is contained within the uploadExcelController.controller.js file. You can adapt the code below for your own application. Make sure to adjust the file name and payload column names to fit your specific needs.

sap.ui.define(
  [
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension",
    "sap/m/MessageToast",
    "sap/ui/core/Fragment",
    "xlsx",
  ],
  function (ControllerExtension, MessageToast, Fragment, XLSX) {
    "use-strict";

    return ControllerExtension.extend(
      "uploadempexcel.ext.controller.uploadExcelController",
      {
        _pDialog: null,
        _file: null,

        uploadExcel: function () {
          if (!this._pDialog) {
            this._pDialog = Fragment.load({
              id: this.base.getView().getId(),
              name: "uploadempexcel.ext.fragment.uploadExcelFragment",
              controller: this,
            }).then(
              function (oDialog) {
                this.base.getView().addDependent(oDialog);
                return oDialog;
              }.bind(this)
            );
          }

          this._pDialog.then(
            function (oDialog) {
              oDialog.open();
              oDialog.getContent()[0].removeAllItems();
              this._file = null;
              var oUploadButton = oDialog.getBeginButton();
              if (oUploadButton) {
                oUploadButton.setEnabled(false);
              }
            }.bind(this)
          );
        },

        onCloseDialog: function () {
          this._pDialog.then(function (oDialog) {
            oDialog.close();
          });
        },

        onAfterItemAdded: function (oEvent) {
          this._file = oEvent.getParameter("item").getFileObject();
          if (this._file) {
            MessageToast.show(
              "File '" + this._file.name + "' is ready for upload."
            );
          }
          this._pDialog.then(
            function (oDialog) {
              var oUploadButton = oDialog.getBeginButton();
              if (oUploadButton) {
                oUploadButton.setEnabled(!!this._file);
              }
            }.bind(this)
          );
        },

        onAfterItemRemoved: function (oEvent) {
          this._file = null;
          this._pDialog.then(function (oDialog) {
            var oUploadButton = oDialog.getBeginButton();
            if (oUploadButton) {
              oUploadButton.setEnabled(false);
            }
          });
          MessageToast.show("File removed.");
        },

        onUploadPress: function () {
          if (!this._file) {
            MessageToast.show("Please select a file first.");
            return;
          }

          var oReader = new FileReader();
          oReader.onload = function (e) {
            try {
              var data = e.target.result;
              var workbook = XLSX.read(data, { type: "buffer" });
              var sheetName = workbook.SheetNames[0];
              var excelData = XLSX.utils.sheet_to_row_object_array(
                workbook.Sheets[sheetName]
              );

              if (excelData.length > 0) {
                this._callOdataService(excelData);
              } else {
                MessageToast.show("No data found in the Excel file.");
              }
            } catch (error) {
              MessageToast.show("Error reading Excel file: " + error.message);
            }
          }.bind(this);

          oReader.readAsArrayBuffer(this._file);
        },

        _callOdataService: function (excelData) {
          try {
            // --- START: FINAL CORRECTED CODE ---
            // Get the main OData V4 model from the view.
            var oModel = this.base.getView().getModel();

            // Create a ListBinding directly for the entity set of the List Report.
            // The path MUST match the 'contextPath' in your manifest.json for the List Report target.
            var oListBinding = oModel.bindList("/ZC_UPLOAD_EMP");
            // --- END: FINAL CORRECTED CODE ---

            if (!oListBinding) {
              // This error is now highly unlikely to occur.
              throw new Error(
                "Could not create a ListBinding for the path /ZC_UPLOAD_EMP."
              );
            }

            excelData.forEach(function (rowData) {
              // IMPORTANT: Make sure your Excel column headers match exactly
              var oPayload = {
                //EmpID: rowData.EmployeeID.toString(), auto generated by Early Numbering in RAP Application
                Empname: rowData.EmployeeName.toString(),
                Contact: rowData.Contact.toString(),
              };
              // The create operation is performed on the ListBinding instance.
              oListBinding.create(oPayload);
            });

            MessageToast.show("Uploading " + excelData.length + " records...");

            // The model holds the batch queue, so we submit the changes on the model.
            oModel
              .submitBatch("$auto")
              .then(
                function () {
                  MessageToast.show("Data uploaded successfully.");
                  this.base.getExtensionAPI().refresh(); // Refresh the table to show new data
                  this.onCloseDialog();
                }.bind(this)
              )
              .catch(function (oError) {
                MessageToast.show("Error during upload: " + oError.message);
              });
          } catch (error) {
            MessageToast.show("Error processing data: " + error.message);
          }
        },
      }
    );
  }
);

Dependencies

Before you can run the application, you'll need to install the necessary dependencies. You can do this by running the following commands in your terminal.

npm i ui5-tooling-modules
npm i xlsx

We also need to update your ui5.yaml file by adding the following custom tasks.

builder:
customTasks:
- name: ui5-tooling-modules-task
afterTask: replaceVersion
- name: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware
afterMiddleware: compression

Conclusion

By following these steps, you can add a fully functional Excel upload feature to your SAP Fiori application. This enhancement provides a more convenient way for users to handle bulk data uploads, ultimately improving the user experience. I have also prepared a demo Excel file with sample data that you can use for testing purposes.

entry.title: Bridging the gap with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper
entry.content:
With the extended maintenance end date rapidly approaching for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition releases 1503, 1603, 1709 - 1909, it is time for impacted customers to start planning their next steps before entering customer-specific maintenance on January 1, 2026.  

Mainstream maintenance, extended maintenance, and customer-specific maintenance are the three distinct maintenance phases applicable to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition under the SAP Maintenance Strategy.  

During mainstream maintenance, full support (SAP Notes, Support packages, Support package stacks, Feature package stacks, etc) is offered for a SAP product until a successor product is available. Extended maintenance offers similar support but requires a specific maintenance contract. For RISE customers, extended maintenance for S/4HANA Cloud private edition is covered by the regular annual subscription fee and does not require a specific maintenance addendum. Once extended maintenance ends, systems enter customer-specific maintenance (CSM), a phase with limited and restricted support services. Entering CSM as a RISE customer means the support and Service Level Agreement currently provided by SAP Enterprise Cloud Services will no longer be available.

 S/4HANA Maintenance Timelines   

  

To fully leverage the value of SAP, it's essential for customers to keep their S/4HANA release up to date - ensuring robust security, continuous innovation and optimal system performance. For this reason, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service has been released to support RISE with SAP customers who have not yet upgraded to the latest S/4HANA Cloud, private edition version and are at risk of falling into customer-specific maintenance.  New customers who have not yet upgraded must upgrade before moving to RISE. Alternatively, they can move to RISE on their current S/4HANA release before entering customer-specific maintenance, as long as they also purchase the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service. Customer-specific maintenance is not supported for new RISE customers. Safekeeper services are only applicable to S/4HANA Cloud releases, not SAP ERP.  

 

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service is purchased as a single sales SKU and includes:  

1) Upgrade Services  

A) SAP Cloud Application Services (CAS) for Release Version Upgrade  

OR  

B) SAP Cloud Application Services (CAS) for Regression Testing   

  

2) Infrastructure  

An additional non-productive sandbox tier is provided by SAP to match the size of the existing production system up to 6TiB.   

 

3) Maintenance-related services  

Your existing S/4HANA landscape entering customer-specific maintenance will continue to receive SAP Notes and corrections generally aligning with the scope of Extended Maintenance. It will mitigate the limitations of the customer-specific maintenance for the contracted period.   

 

Let’s look at two real-world scenarios.   

Example #1 In-Place Upgrade from S/4HANA 1809 to S/4HANA 2023

I'm a RISE with SAP customer running SAP S/4HANA release 1809 which will enter customer-specific maintenance on January 1st, 2026.   I want to upgrade my existing systems to SAP S/4HANA 2023.   

In this scenario, the customer purchases SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper at least 90 days prior to the safekeeper contract start date (Sept-30-2025) and opts for the upgrade service a) CAS for Release Version Upgrade. Customer has a production system RAM of 1TB.

As of January 1, 2026, the safekeeper service will be initiated. This includes:   

  •   Deployment of the sandbox infrastructure (copy of existing production system running S/4HANA 1809)    
  • Commencement of the CAS services  
  • SAP Notes and corrections on the existing S/4HANA 1809 landscape  

Following the infrastructure deployment, an upgrade planning workshop is scheduled with CAS delivery team to provide a detailed project plan. Any additional infrastructure for a parallel landscape (e.g. development/ testing) will need to be procured separately. SAP specialists guide, navigate, and support the upgrade/update process as a whole. On-going support is offered until the production go-live.   

Example Brownfield Scenario  

  

Further reading  
CAS for Release Version Upgrade Scope Document: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/agreements/services/scope-documents.html?sort=latest_desc&search=release%20version%20upgrade   

How to upgrade blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/upgrade-your-sap-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-following-sap-activate/ba-p/13956251   

 

#2 Greenfield/ Selective Data Transition  

I'm a RISE with SAP customer running SAP S/4HANA release 1909 entering customer-specific maintenance on January 1, 2026.  I do not want to upgrade my existing systems, but instead, implement a new installation of systems on a more current release.   

In this scenario, the suitable upgrade service is b) CAS for Regression Testing.   

As of January 1, 2026, the safekeeper service will be initiated. This includes:   

  •   Deployment of the sandbox infrastructure (empty greenfield system with the desired target release e.g. 2023)    
  • Commencement of the CAS package for Regression Testing  
  • SAP Notes and corrections on the existing S/4HANA 1909 landscape  

Implementing a greenfield S/4HANA deployment typically involves replicating or redesigning previous business processes or adopting SAP best practices. These processes can be tested and validated in the new sandbox environment before implementing in other tiers. Customer will need to procure additional systems (DEV, QAS and PRD) based on the project plan.

Example Greenfield Scenario  

  

Further reading  

Regression Testing Service Scope Document: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/agreements/services/scope-documents.html?sort=latest_desc&search=SAP%20Cloud%20Application%20services%20for%20regression%20testing   

  

As SAP S/4HANA 1503 and 1605 were built on an ECC solution stack, customers running these releases will require a system conversion to a more recent SAP S/4HANA release. In this scenario, CAS for Release Version Upgrade does not apply, and the CAS for Regression Testing will be offered.   

  

Contract Duration  

The minimum contract duration for Safekeeper is 12 months and the maximum is 27 months (or up to 48 months in case of releases 1503 & 1605). Customers are expected to have moved to a more current release within mainstream maintenance by the end of their contracted period. Extensions are available for customers who did not purchase the full term initially.  

 

Add-ons  

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper services are available for selected add-ons within the scope of RISE with SAP, as set forth in the list attached to the following SAP Note 3424346. This list will be expanded as new products are added, so it is recommended to check back frequently if you plan to use Safekeeper.   

  

Extract from the SAP S4HANA Cloud Safekeeper Add-on List  

 

The single source of truth for Safekeeper availability is the SAP Product Availability Matrix at https://support.sap.com/pam  

Please note that add-ons having a longer mainstream maintenance date than Safekeeper availability for the specific release will not be included in the list attached to the SAP note. However, such add-ons will still be covered by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper services.   

  

Conclusion  

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper has been introduced to support RISE with SAP customers in their transition to a more current SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition release. By providing structured upgrade or reimplementation paths, enabled by SAP Cloud Application Services, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper bridges the gap between the end of extended maintenance and the adoption of a current S/4HANA release, helping RISE customers maintain their support and SLAs from the SAP Enterprise Cloud Services organization.
