entry.title: Developing a Customized AR Aging Analysis Report in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction:

Hello everyone, Myself Sriram Balaji, I am currently working as an SAP FICO Consultant. Last year, I got an opportunity to work in SAP Public Cloud Greenfield Implementation Project. During the “FIT to Standard” and “UAT” sessions, we have demonstrated the SAP standard Customer / Supplier Aging Analysis Report to the client but they are not satisfied with the standard aging report. They required a tailored Aging Analysis Report for Customer and Supplier, one that aligned perfectly with their unique operational requirements. This experience highlighted the importance of understanding client expectations beyond standard functionalities and fueled my journey into customizing SAP solutions in the Public Cloud.

In this blog, we are going to explore how we can develop Customized Customer (AR) Aging Analysis Report using the “Key User Extensibility” in the SAP Public Cloud.

 

Purpose of Preparing Customer Aging Analysis Report:

Customer Aging Analysis Report, is a basic financial report which provides the information of outstanding payment from the customer’s and how long they are due for the payment by categorizing into the Aging Buckets (0 – 30 Days, 31 – 60 Days, ……. Above 365 Days).

The aging report provides vital information to management to evaluate how effective the business is at converting sales to cash. The aging report is also used as a tool for estimating potential bad debts, which are then used to revise what is known as the allowance for doubtful accounts.

 

Key-User Extensibility in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud:

Extensibility covers a broad spectrum of topics that enable customers and partners to adapt standard business software to their business needs.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud key user extensibility allows adapting standard functionalities to user requirements without the need for any external tools. Key User Extensibility is done in the customizing tenant of the development system through SAP Fiori apps designed to facilitate someone making small changes to apps, reports, and email and form templates without any coding experience.

Here's an overview of the things you can do using key user extensibility tools:

  • Change and adapt the UIs for SAP Fiori Apps
  • Create Custom Fields
  • Create your own custom templates or extend the standard forms and email templates
  • Create customer-specific CDS Views
  • Enhance the current business process by creating custom business logic
  • Create a new custom user interface
  • Create custom business objects

SAP S/4HANA embodies key user extensibility tools, which are completely web-based. They are targeted at key users who have a deep knowledge of the product itself, but not necessarily a very deep technical knowledge.

For more details about Extensibility in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud, please refer the link https://extensibilityexplorer.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/ExtensibilityExplorer/#/ReadMore

To develop the Customized Customer Aging Analysis Report, we are going to use the below Key-User Extensibility Apps and other provided Apps by SAP in the Public Cloud:

  • Custom CDS View APP
  • Custom Analytical Queries APP
  • View Browser APP
  • Custom Catalog Extensions APP

My prior experience in developing Aging Analysis Reports in SAP ECC and S/4HANA GUI with my technical team allowed me to apply the same logic to Custom CDS Views and Custom Analytical Queries, even without knowing any deep technical knowledge.

Let me summarize the business requirement for Customer Aging Analysis before jumping into the technical steps involved for the development:

  • The report should display: Customer Account, Customer Name, Document Number, Line Item, Document Type, GL Account, Payment Terms (with descriptions), and other required fields.
  • The report should calculate and present: Overdue Days, Not Yet Due, Aging Buckets (0-30 days, 31-60 days, …... and Above 365 days), and Total Overdue Amount.
  • The report balances must be matched with the 'Manage Customer Line Items' App (Accounts Receivable Ledger).

 

In this Part - 1, We will explore how we can utilize the Custom CDS View APP for the AR Aging Analysis Report development.

 

Custom CDS View:

Custom CDS views can serve different purposes: They can be consumed in analytics or serve as external APIs to be consumed in external systems, for instance the SAP BTP. Especially Cube or Dimension views can be used in analytical scenarios and also you can create or modify a custom CDS view by,

  • Adding fields from multiple data sources.
  • Creating your own calculated fields.
  • Refining the properties of the selected fields.
  • Creating and maintaining parameters for the usage within your view.

We have combined the multiple data sources such as I_JournalEntryOperationalView, _I_GLAccountText, and _I_PaymentTermsText to create a Custom CDS View by using the Join Condition.

 

Step – 1: Open the APP – Custom CDS View

Click on “Create”.

 

Enter the “Label”, Choose the “Scenario” – “Analytical Cube” and Click on “Create” Button.

Note: By choosing the Scenario as “Analytical Cube”, We can use this CDS View to create an Analytical Queries for the Customer Aging Analysis report.

 

Step – 2: Choose the Primary Data Source 

Click on “Add” Button

Choose the “Primary Data Source”

Note: Data Source is an object containing the key figures and characteristics from the database and it provides a multidimensional analytical view of business data.

 

Select the respective “I_JournalEntryOperationalView” Data Source from the list.

 

This I_JournalEntryOperationalView CDS view provides access to all details of a journal entry item (database table ACDOCA) joined to the details of the corresponding operational accounting document item (database table BSEG) and to the details of the corresponding journal entry header (database table BKPF) including the most important business entity, such as G/L account, Cost Center or Profit Center.

So, this I_JournalEntryOperationalView is similar to the ACDOCA Table which contains the values of all the relevant fields related to the Accounting Document.

 

Step – 3: Choose the Associated Data Sources

Click on “Associated Data Sources”

Note: Associated Data Sources will help us to combine the two different data sources into one CDS View by using a join condition set between two or more equal characteristics present in the Primary Data Source – A and Associated Date Sources – B that contains the same data type.

For Example:

The primary data source "I_JournalEntryOperationalView" does not include the "Payment Terms Description" field. Therefore, we must join it with the associated data source "I_PaymentTermsText" using a join condition to retrieve this field.

Select the “Join Condition” Icon.

 

Click on “Add”

 

Choose the common field that available in the both Primary & Associated Data Source to join.

 

Select the Value Type as “Field”

Click on F4 in the Value Field.

 

Find the corresponding "Payment Terms" mapping field in the Primary Data Source to link it with the field in the Associated Data Source.

 

Select the Value Type as “Session Variable”

Choose the Value as “System Language” and Click on “Close” button.

 

Step – 4: Choose the Elements (Fields) to be added in the CDS View

In the Elements Section, Click on “Add” button and Choose “Elements”.

In the Elements selection pop up screen,

Choose the “Elements (Fields)” from “I_JournalEntryOperationalView” you want to display in the CDS view and then Click on “OK”.

Total 142 Elements (Fields) have been selected for the CDS view.

 

Step – 5: Create User Defined Parameters

User-Defined Parameters:

Parameters usually require data input when your custom CDS view is executed. This data can then be used like a variable e.g. in filters, calculated fields or even in a join condition to another view. You can then refine them or just create your own parameters if you need them.

The Customer Aging Analysis Report will operate based on "Open Items at Key Date," mirroring the functionality found in reports like "Manage Customer Line Item" or "FBL5N."

The "Open Items at Key Date" logic ensures that when the report is run for a specific date (which can be in the past, present, or future), it will only display items that meet following criteria mentioned below:

  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were not yet cleared as of the specified key date will be included in the report.
  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were cleared after the specified key date will be included in the report.
  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were cleared before the specified key date will be excluded from the report.

This "Key Date" will serve as a crucial input on the report's selection screen, driving the logic for determining which open items are included in the Customer Aging Report.

In the Parameters Section, Click on “Add” button,

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Data Type: “DATS” – Date (YYYYMMDD Format) Data type of the parameter.
  • Default Type and Value: “Manual” - Enter a manual parameter value in accordance with the data type syntax, e.g. for the data type DATS enter a manual value in the format YYYYMMDD.

Now the “Open Items at Key Date” Parameter is created. 

 

Step – 6: Add User Defined Parameters in the Elements (Fields)

In the Elements Section, Click on “Add” Button and Choose the “Parameters”.

Select the created “Open Items at Key Date” Parameter and Click on “OK” button.

Now the “Open Items at Key Date” Parameter has been added in the Elements.

 

Step – 7: Using “Filter” Applying the Logic for the Customer Aging Analysis Report

You can filter the information shown in your custom CDS view by setting up a condition, just like using the WHERE clause in SQL. This condition provides the view exactly what data to show.

Think of it like this:

The CDS view (I_JournalEntryOperationalView) which we are using that shows all the Accounting Document transactions in line item wise.

  • If you want to display only Customer related Accounting Transactions, you'd set a condition like "Account Type is equal to “D".
  • Or, if you only want to see Normal Transactions (Invoices, Payments) & Special GL Transactions (Advances), your condition would be "Special GL Code equal to “BLANK”, & “A”.

Once you set this condition (using either a simple editor or a form-based one), your CDS view will automatically filter its results, showing only the open items that match what you asked for. It's a way to fine-tune the data you see without having to look through everything.

We can use the form-based version to define simple filter conditions. In case you want to define more complex conditions, we can use expression-based version. Here, we have used expression-based version.

As per business requirement, to ensure the Customer Aging Analysis Report balances match with the "Manage Customer Line Items" balances, we've set up specific conditions for these fields: Account Type, Special GL Code, Posting Date, and Clearing Date in the Filter section using expression-based version.

 

Step – 8: Create Calculation Elements (Fields) – Overdue Days & Payment Terms Days

In the Elements section, click on “Add” button and Choose “Calculation” to create Overdue Days & Payment Terms Days fields for the report.

  1. Overdue Days

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Choose as “Function” and Choose “Function Type – Date and Time”
  • Choose the respective “Function - DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN” and apply the below mentioned formula.
  • Then click on “Create”.

Note: The function DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN calculates the difference between two specified dates, date1 and date2, in days. The actual parameters must have the predefined data type DATS and should contain a valid date in the format YYYYMMDD.

The Formula we have applied to calculate the Overdue Days is Open Items Key Date (which was created as parameter for report execution) MINUS Net Due Date. 

 

  1. Payment Terms Days

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Choose as “Function” and Choose “Function Type – Date and Time”
  • Choose the respective “Function - DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN” and apply the below mentioned formula.
  • Then click on “Create”.

The Formula we have applied to calculate the Payment Terms Days is Net Due Date MINUS Baseline Date.

Created Calculation Elements (Fields) for the report.

In the Element Properties Section, Maintain the Aggregation method as “No Operation” for the created Payment Term Days & Overdue Days Fields to convert the field into calculated measure for creating the Aging Buckets in the Custom Analytical Query APP.

 

Step – 9: Preview and Publish the created CDS view

In the Log section, check any error need to rectified before preview the CDS view.

Click on “Preview Data” button to display the values are coming as per the logic or not.

 

Created CDS View no of line items are matching with the Manage Customer Line Items.

Calculated Fields (Overdue Days, Payment Terms Days) are displaying with values in the CDS View according formula we have applied in the calculation function.

Once Check is successful, Go to “Next Steps” section.

Click on “Publish” button to publish the Created CDS View for Creating Analytical Queries.

In Part - 2, we'll dive into using the Custom Analytical Queries APP with our newly created Custom CDS View to build an AR Aging Analysis Report.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA configuration for SAC pull of plan data
entry.content:
This post deals with the SAP S/4HANA app “Manage Financial Plan Data Jobs - for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration” (in the following referred to as “manage” app) where mandatory configuration settings for pulling plan data from SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) into SAP S/4HANA tables like ACDOCP or FINSSKF are defined. These configuration settings are prerequisite for the app “Schedule Financial Plan Data Jobs for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration“ to execute a financial plan data job (for data replication). The integration using these two apps is available in SAP S/4HANA Public and Private Cloud Edition.

The goal is to provide guidance on the necessary configuration settings in this manage app and show example configurations based on SAC content for different use cases.

It is recommended to bookmark this post, as we plan to enhance it with further recommendations and configuration settings.

Before creating a configuration, first in the manage app a tenant ID (with communication details) of a SAP Analytics Cloud tenant must be defined which is explained in the following online help:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/1cbcff7ccd35405ab445b223c1ab1588/1d0a86ae5db84da89a56481e9e73b5cf.html?locale=en-US
  • SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/48f4b4785b8e45938ac44a67be8032d9/1d0a86ae5db84da89a56481e9e73b5cf.html?locale=en-US

This post is based on the following SAC content for Integrated Financial Planning with possible plan data replications into S/4HANA tables but apply to other (customer specific) SAC models writing into these S/4HANA tables as well.

To simplify, we assume that depreciations are copied from the SAC model CAPEX to model OPEX and asset values ​​from the SAC model CAPEX to model Financial Statement Planning. So we only deal with configuration entries for plan data related to OPEX, Sales and Profitability Planning and Financial Statement. CO2 values ​​are also ignored (might be addressed in a later version of this post).

We start with functional and technical basics, continue with general recommendations and finally show some example configurations.

Functional Basics

For replication of plan data related to the three IFP models OPEX, Profitability and Financial Statement into SAP S/4HANA, the following SAC modeling details must be considered:

  • In contrast to Profitability and Financial Statement, only OPEX has a dimension for the debit/credit indicator to represent cost charges and discharges. However, for profitability and financial statement data, the debit/credit indicator ‘D’ is added by default when writing into table ACDOCP. The debit/credit indicator becomes part of the plan data scope explained below.
  • When transferring sales and administration costs from OPEX to Profitability, the same account used to post into Profitability is used to credit records in OPEX. However, in contrast to OPEX, product and plant information is added to these costs in Profitability.
  • The starting point for financial statement planning is a copy of actual data from the previous year’s financial statement. Then plan data from OPEX and Profitability are copied into Financial Statement, i.e. these copy processes do NOT result in corresponding credit records on the sender side.
  • The IFP content in SAC offers two possible sources for bringing a profit and loss statement into table ACDOCP:
    • Option 1: The model Financial Statement serves as the source to ensure a complete P&L statement. Since the copy of actual data is used as a starting point, the data can contain recurring extraordinary revenues and costs like the dissolution of accruals etc. 
    • Option 2: The two models OPEX and Profitability serve as the source. Here special attention is required for the account(s) used to transfer sales and administration costs from OPEX to Profitability (more on this later). In contrast to Option 1, this option has only operating costs and revenues.

Technical Basics

It is important to understand that contrary to table ACDOCA, table ACDOCP represents a multidimensional view. Therefore, the key fields of table ACDOCP consist of purely technical fields. This makes it necessary to specify a so-called aggregation level and plan data scope when writing data into table ACDOCP. These are explained below (among other technical terms for the Manage app).

  1. Aggregation level
    The aggregation level determines the fields of the records for which plan data is transferred into SAP S/4HANA. In the following mapping view of the configuration for the SAC plan data pull, the listed SAP S/4HANA fields are automatically translated into this aggregation level:
    As you can see in the last four columns of the screenshot above, it does not matter for the derivation of the aggregation level whether the field is mapped 1:1 from SAC, derived from an attribute (of an SAC dimension), or defined as a fixed value.
  2. Plan Data Scope
    The plan data scope influences which existing data records in table ACDOCP are replaced by the new plan data. Therefore, based on the fields marked “In Scope” (i.e. plan data scope) and their corresponding values from the plan data (to be written into ACDOCP), a data set is identified in the (multidimensional) table ACDOCP.
    It is important to understand that for the derivation of this “data set” not only the existing value combinations from the fields marked as “In Scope” are used, but also cross-combinations of these field values (see example 3 below).
    The following three scenarios show how new plan data with the respective plan data scope setting overwrites existing data in table ACDOCP.

    The more fields are added to the plan data scope, the fewer existing records can be overwritten with the new data, and thus the impacted data section is smaller (see example 2). This is also the reason why some fields such as the planning category or time-related fields like LedgerFiscalYear or FiscalYearPeriod are mandatory in the plan data scope, so that more data than desired is not accidentally overwritten when writing plan data into ACDOCP.
    In the configuration of the manage application, the plan data scope is defined in following highlighted column of the mapping view.
  3. Interaction between update mode and plan data scope
    Because the update mode for reading the relevant plan data records in SAC is a full update, SAC data is always written as a “whole” into table ACDOCP. Therefore, for cost-center-related costs, for example, FiscalYearPeriod and GLAccount should not be added to the plan data scope (to replace the existing cost-center-related accounts and periods with the new plan data). Another example are project-related costs, where the WBSElement, FiscalYearPeriod and GLAccount should not be added to the plan data scope. This ensures that the new plan data from SAC replaces the existing data in ACDOCP correctly.
  4. Account selection
    In the Filter Settings section of a configuration ID in the Manage app, meaningful data selections via G/L accounts are limited, as hierarchy nodes are not supported for the account field. For example, selecting primary accounts, cost accounts or balance sheet accounts using hierarchy nodes is not supported. Unfortunately, this type of selection is only possible via flat account selection, where the relevant accounts are then listed.
  5. Lock concept for writing into table ACDOCP
    Given that the lock concept for writing into table ACDOCP is based on the SAP S/4HANA fields PlanningCategory, ControllingArea, CompanyCode and LedgerFiscalYear, simultaneously running pull jobs into the same planning category can lock each other (for overlapping controlling areas, company code and fiscal year). However, in SAP S/4HANA no locks can occur if simultaneous pull jobs are writing into different planning categories. Therefore this should be considered when using multiple configuration IDs.

General configuration-specific recommendations

After clarifying some functional and technical basics, let’s look at the following recommendations for the configuration:

  • In general, overlapping plan data across different configurations which are written into the same planning category inevitably leads to inconsistent data when running the financial plan data jobs for the respective configuration IDs (due to the conflict with the plan data scope and subsequent mutual overwriting). An example of this is the configuration for (total) expenses and another configuration specifically for project-related expenses (subset of total expenses). Therefore, it is important to avoid such cases by defining different plan categories in the mapping section for the SAP S/4HANA field PlanningCategory.
  • Plan data from the IFP model Financial Statement must always kept in a separate planning category (in contrast to plan data from the IFP models OPEX and Sales & Profitability) to avoid inconsistencies due to duplicate figures. The reason is that OPEX und Sales & Profitability data is copied into the SAC model Financial Statement without crediting on the sender side.
  • In the case of writing OPEX and Profitability data into one planning category (for an alternative P&L report in SAP S/4HANA), having the field GLAccount as an additional “In Scope” field helps differentiate the two data sets (to avoid mutual overwrite), if OPEX and Sales & Profitability use different GL accounts. However, if, for example, a single GL account is used to transfer sales and administration costs from OPEX to Sales and Profitability, this approach no longer ensures disjoint data, and the plan data scope must be expanded. If, as shown in the following example, OPEX consists only of cost center data (and is marked as “In Scope”), and all Sales & Profitability data has a Plant, Sold Material and Customer allocation (and is marked as “In Scope”), disjoint data is ensured as well (without mutual overwrite):
  • A mapping of profit center and functional area values for a given configuration ID in the view ”Mapping of Financial Plan Data” ​​(to transfer both fields from SAC) is optional for OPEX and Profitability, since both would be automatically derived in the ACDOCP write interface if missing. If, however, Profit Center and Functional Area are mapped (and thus transferred from SAC), the correct profit center and functional area assignment is checked in SAP S/4HANA before writing plan data into table ACDOCP.  If this consistency check fails because, for example, the derived account assignment type returns a different profit center, an error message appears and the data transfer is aborted. Therefore, when mapping the functional area and/or profit center, ensure that the master data in SAP Analytics Cloud is up to date.
  • When using the SAP-delivered planning categories BUDGET01, BUDGET02 and BUDGET03 when writing into table ACDOCP,  the following default value for Budget Consistency Check (screenshot taken from SSCUI ID 102822) requires that additional (plan data scope) requirements be taken into account:For example, for project budget (planning category BUDGET01), plan data scope must NOT be active for WBSElement, FiscalPeriod, FiscalYearPeriod and CompanyCode. For the cost center budget (planning category BUDGET02), plan data scope must NOT be active for FiscalPeriod and FiscalYearPeriod.
  • Balance sheet data as part of financial statement planning requires a balance carry-forward logic to ensure that opening balance and balance sheet movements within a fiscal year are correctly replicated from SAC into table ACDOCP. Like in the SAC Export API, this requires mapping of the SAP S/4HANA global field BalanceFlowType (see in below file configuration ID 30001).
  • Costs split into fixed and variable costs in SAC can also be replicated and stored in table ACDOCP, which requires mapping of the SAP S/4HANA field FixedVariableType. In this case, the data records split into fixed and variable are merged into one data record on the SAP S/4HANA side, i.e. the total value (sum of fixed and variable) is written to the respective “total” measures (e.g. AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency) and the fixed value is written into the respective fixed measure (e.g. FixedAmountInCoCodeCrcy).

Example Configurations

Finally, the file in the following URL shows predefined configuration settings to give an idea of how to configure specific content in the mapping and filter section: https://d.dam.sap.com/a/MVuKTRq?rc=10&doi=SAP1225684

The first example (configuration ID 10001) from the file for OPEX-related plan data on cost centers and projects, including value-based allocations, is explained based on screenshots from the manage app:

Mapping of Financial Plan Data

  • For the SAC measure AMOUNT on the SAP S/4HANA side, the measure AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency is used (and the currency derived from a property of the company code), assuming the company code currency in SAC plan data.
  • The displayed plan data scope contains the mandatory plan data scope fields PlanningCategory, CompanyCode and FiscalYearPeriod (or LedgerFiscalYear) and is sufficient if there is no other overlapping configuration ID writing into the same planning category.
  • As described, ProfitCenter and FunctionalArea are not included, as this proposal relies on the derivation rules in SAP S/4HANA to derive the two fields in the background when writing plan data into table ACDOCP.
  • Including the source field FixedVariableType ensures that when writing into table ACDOCP the plan data is reformatted accordingly, i.e. the total value (sum of fixed and variable) is written to the respective “total” measures (e.g. AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency) and the fixed value is written to the respective fixed measure (e.g. FixedAmountInCoCodeCrcy).
  • In the example, the SAP Planning category PLN is used. Likewise, another category can be selected, which is maintained in SAP S/4HANA with Application Type “Periodic Planning & Consolidation” and Category Usage “NO specific usage” (in SSCUI 101970, Maintain Category for Planning).

Filter Settings for Financial Plan Data

  • The mandatory single value filter for the source field Version is maintained here. In the IFP content, the version Plan is used by default and may need to be adjusted if it differs in the custom data model.
  • It should also be filtered by planning period to select the plan data to the respective planning year.
  • In this example, further filter settings are not necessary because, on the one hand, this configuration is for OPEX-related plan data including cost centers and projects and only the AMOUNT measure is mapped. Other measures are excluded (like measures related to allocation weights ).

entry.title: Developing a Customized AR Aging Analysis Report in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Part 2
entry.content:
In this Part - 2, we'll dive into using the Custom Analytical Queries APP with our newly created Custom CDS View to build an AR Aging Analysis Report.

 

Please refer Part - 1 to Understand the Custom CDS View created for the AR Aging Analysis Report:

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-q-a/developing-a-customized-ar-aging-analysis-report-in-sap-s-4hana-public/qaq-p/14163727

 

Custom Analytical Queries APP:

The Custom Analytical Queries APP is like a smart tool that helps you create your own reports and analyze your business data, even if you're not a tech expert.

Imagine you're trying to build your Customer Aging Analysis Report. Instead of writing complex computer code, this app takes all the raw numbers and information (like invoices, payments, and dates) and turns them into an easy-to-understand table or grid. It hides all the difficult technical stuff, so you just focus on what you want to see.

Here's how it helps you design your report:

Pick and choose your data: The app provides all the available fields from the business transactions. For your aging report, you'd select fields like Customer Name, Invoice Number, Posting Date, Due Date, Amount Due, and Clearing Date.

Filter what you see: You can set filters to narrow down your report. For example, you might filter to see only particular customers, or invoices past their due date by more than 365 days.

Create custom calculations: You can add restricted measures (like "Total Overdue Amount for 30-60 Days").

See results instantly: You can preview your report as you build it, so you know exactly what the final output will look like.

 

Step – 1: Open the APP – Custom Analytical Queries

Click on “Create” button.

 

Enter the “Query Name”, Choose the “Data Source” – which we have created as a CDS View.

Click on “OK”.

 

Step – 2: Name the Analytical Query

In the General Tab,

Enter the “Label” for the AR Aging Analysis Analytical Query and Click on Next Tab “Field Selection”.

 

Step – 3: Field Selection for the Analytical Query

In the Field Selection Tab,

Choose the required fields from the Available Fields by selecting the “Check box” to display in the AR Aging Report.

 

Step – 4: Arrange the Selected Fields in the Analytical Query

In the Display Tab,

Select relevant Field and Choose the “Axis” - Row / Column. Once selected the Axis, the field will be automatically moved to Row / Column Tab same as Company Code, Customer etc.

Note: Arrange the fields according to the business format and also Amounts / Numerical / Calculation related fields are arranged under the Measure Structure of Column Axis.

 

Step – 5: Choose the Input Parameter Fields for the Report

For the AR Aging Analysis Report, users need to provide input parameters such as Open Items at Key Date, Customer, Company Code, GL Account, and Posting Date to generate the report based on their selections.

In the Filter Tab,

Choose the respective Field and then Select the radio button “Uset Input Values”.

Select the “Default Value” if required.

Note: Our AR Aging Analysis report runs based on the Open Items at Key Date, showing all items not cleared by that date. If you need to pre-fill any input fields, you can use the Default Value functionality in the filter section.

For Example: Below are the selected Input Parameters for our report and the “Open Items at Key Date” and “Company Code” will be defaulted at the time of report execution based on the settings in Analytical Queries.

Step – 6: Create Calculated Measure Fields (Aging Buckets) for the Report

Creating Aging Buckets is the most challenging aspect of developing the AR Aging Analysis Report. This is primarily due to the complexity of applying the necessary formulas. To build custom aging buckets, you'll need a foundational understanding of IF & Else conditions, similar to those used in Excel, to grasp the CASE WHEN Expression formulas utilized in SAP Analytical Queries.

 

  1. Not Yet Due (Aging Bucket - 1)

In the Display Tab,

Click on “Add” button and Choose “Add Calculated Measure” to create the Aging Bucket.

Then Enter the “Label” and Click on “OK”.

We've now added a "Not Yet Due" field to the query. This field displays the Amount in Company Code Currency for any customer open items with Overdue Days less than or equal to zero.

The above logic has been applied in the analytical query using the CASE WHEN formula.

In the Expression Section,

Choose the “Edit” button to apply the formula.

Select the “Function” button then Choose the “Case Expression” and Click on “OK” button.

The formula applied in this “Not Yet Due” field is, if the Overdue days field is less than or equal to “0” then “Amount in Company Code Currency” should be displayed in the report or Else the value should be displayed as “0”. You can Choose the Measure fields by click on measures button or else you can type relevant measure field in the Expression editor. Once formula applied the Click on “OK”.

 

  1. 1 to 30 Days (Aging Bucket – 2)

Apply the same steps involved in Not Yet Due field, only the formula will be changed for this 1 to 30 Days Aging Bucket.

For the "1 to 30 Days" field, we've applied a specific formula:

If a Customer Open item's Overdue Days are greater than or equal to "1" AND less than or equal to "30," the Amount in Company Code Currency will be displayed. Otherwise, the value will show as "0." This formula uses an AND condition to accurately identify customer open items that are between 1 and 30 days overdue.

After applying the formula, simply click "OK."

 You can apply this formula and change the conditions according to the Aging Buckets (31 to 60 Days, 61 to 90 Days…etc).

The Sum of all the Aging Buckets from “1 to 30 Days till Above 365 Days” will be the “Total Overdue Amount”.

Once the respective fields created in the Custom Analytical Queries APP.

Click on “Save Draft” the changes will be saved. Then click on “Preview” option to validate the report values.

 

Step – 7: Preview and Validate the Created Custom Analytical Query

In the Input Parameters, The Open Items at Key Date and Company Code will automatically default the value according to the settings in Custom Analytical Queries APP and also it can be changeable at the time of report executing.

Once maintained the Input Parameters, Click on “GO”.

You can validate the output of the report in the Preview. So, the issues will be identified and resolved before publishing the Custom Analytical Query for the APP creation.

 

Step – 8: Publish the Created Custom Analytical Query for AR Aging Analysis Report

Click on “Publish” to publish the created Custom Analytical Query for the AR Aging Analysis Report APP creation.

 

View Browser APP:

For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition key users, the View Browser app is essential for finding CDS views. This includes both SAP-released and custom CDS views.

The app provides a comprehensive list of available CDS views. You can see details like Category, View Types, Dimensions and Measures, Annotations, supported capabilities, and modelling patterns. It also offers robust search options. You can search by descriptions, application components, or even the tables used to build the CDS views.

Beyond searching, you can use the View Browser to analyze a CDS view's data fields. The application displays all CDS views and their underlying artifacts in tables. By default, views are organized by name, but you can also filter column values using a dropdown.

While you can't change SAP-created CDS views in the View Browser, the Custom Analytical Query app allows you to create, save, modify, and publish your own CDS views to catalogs.

 

Step – 1: Create the Application for Created Custom Analytical Query

Open the “View Browser” APP.

Search the Created AR Aging Analysis Analytical Query in the Search Bar and then Click on the respective Analytical Query to Create the Application.

You can check the Fields, and CDS View involved in this Analytical Query.

Click on “Create Application”.

Choose the “Language”

Enter the “Title” and “Subtitle” for the Report and this will be the Application Name.

Click on “OK”.

Finally, the Application is created for the developed AR Aging Analysis Report.

 

Custom Catalog Extensions APP:

This app lets you assign your apps to specific business catalogs. After creating a new app, you must link it to the necessary catalogs. To use your new app, you'll need to assign a business role that includes that Catalog.

 

Step – 1: Open the APP – Custom Catalog Extensions

Select the Created Application to assign it to the respective Business Catalog.

 

Step – 2: Assign Business Catalog to the Application

Click on “ADD”.

 

Choose the respective “Business Catalog” and then Click on “OK”.

Select the Business Catalog and then Click on “Publish” button.

Confirm by choosing the “OK” to publish.

Finally, the Created Application is assigned with the Business Catalog and published for the business usage.

 

Step – 3: Display the APP - AR Aging Analysis – Report

Once the APP is assigned with the Business Catalog, you can search the created APP in the search bar to display it for the reporting purpose.

 

References / Acknowledgements:

I'd like to extend my sincere thanks to the various SAP documentation, community blogs, and helpful tutorials that guided me through the intricacies of Key User Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

I highly recommend them for anyone looking to dive deeper into SAP S/4HANA Cloud extensibility:

  1. https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/customer-aging-and-supplier-aging-reports-at-the-line-item-level-using/ba-p/13563839
  2. https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/creating-custom-cds-views-and-analytical-query-a-step-by-step-guide/ba-p/13508914
  3. https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/e30de6eae4d24d70b65996ac8ff88848.html?locale=en-US&version=2502.500

 

Conclusion:

Developing a customized Customer AR Aging Analysis Report in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, as demonstrated, truly highlights the power and flexibility of "Key User Extensibility." While standard solutions offer a solid foundation, the ability to adapt and build tailored reports is crucial for meeting unique business requirements and ensuring user satisfaction.

By leveraging apps like Custom CDS Views, Custom Analytical Queries, the View Browser, and Custom Catalog Extensions, key users can effectively design and deploy robust financial reports without extensive technical coding. This empowers organizations to gain deeper insights into their financial data, streamline processes, and make more informed decisions regarding accounts receivable management.

This project was a testament to how SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition enables businesses to go beyond standard functionalities, proving that with the right tools and a clear understanding of business needs, powerful custom solutions are well within reach.

Thank You!

entry.title: Workarounds for Planning inconsistancies occuring due to MRP live
entry.content:
Planning Inconsistency during MRP run using MRP live

Introduction

             Material Requirements Planning (MRP) is one of the core components within the Production Planning module of SAP ERP. Its primary function is to ensure material availability by systematically evaluating demand (PIR, CIR, S/O), existing inventory and procurement proposals (PRs/POs), and generating new proposals to bridge any identified shortages. This is essential for smooth production operations and timely delivery schedules

             As the 21st century unfolded, it ushered into a new age – The digital age, the Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR), our period is marked by rapid digital transformation across industries. Every facet of the supply chain is being shifted toward digitization as much as possible, driven by the need for increased speed, transparency, efficiency, connectivity and scalability. At the same time, the volume and complexity of global business transactions surged, placing unprecedented pressure on legacy systems.

            In response to these evolving market needs, enterprise resource planning systems required a significant upgrade. The modern market needs 4IR compliant features such as such as high-capacity data storage and data retrieval, cloud computing, integration with IoT networks, intelligent automation through AI-ML and system scalability.

            Recognizing this shift, SAP launched its next-generation business suite—SAP S/4HANA—in February 2015. One of its most transformative innovations (P.P. POV) was the introduction of MRP Live, a high-performance planning engine designed to meet the demands of real-time, data-driven operations, built to leverage the power of the HANA database, executes complex planning scenarios at unprecedented speed, with scalability and transparency tailored to the digital enterprise.

            However, as with any emerging technology during it’s infancy, MRP live also has it’s own constraints. More details of its restrictions are available on S/Note: 1914010. This article describes a scenario of planning inconsistency of MRP live and a work around to fix it.

Disclaimer

This observation is shared purely for educational purposes only and pertains to a specific scenario. MRP Live is a powerful and innovative tool, with high flexibility and possess robust cross-plant planning capabilities. The behavior noted here is an outlier case within a highly complex program. While a temporary workaround is suggested, it’s important to emphasize that, the final solution must come from SAP, as part of their continuous product improvement and support lifecycle."

Business Scenario

The material is maintained as a project stock. We maintain a planned independent requirement and procure the components, at the same time, we also receive sales orders. Sales order consumes PIR. Basically, it follows Planning with Final assembly, but with two changes:

  1. Since it’s under project stock, therefore for CIR, we assign assignment category “Q”
  2. The business scenario is such that, when S/O is created, Production order also need to be created automatically.

Configurations 

Practice scenario:

PIR:

Sales Order:

Stock Requirements screen:

We can observe two things

  1. Sales Order has consumed PIR.
  2. Production orders are created without MRP run as soon as Sales orders are saved.

Now Planning run using MRP live

 

Stock Requirements screen:

Pic: A

Creating a second sales order and executing MRP live:

Pic B

Observations

  1. Sales order consuming PIR properly – Working as per standard.
  2. Compare Pic A & B, for Planned orders created from PIR, the latest sales order details are populated, to its account assignment category – Planning inconsistency

Workarounds

Option 1: T-code: MD_MRP_FORCE_CLASSIC

To correct this planning inconsistency, we must force this material to plan in classic MRP, no matter if planning run is done via classic MRP or MRP live. Refer to S/Note: 2883907 for further information. Although we get the correct planning results, we lose the advantages of MRP live.

Planning run with MRP live.

Result

Observation:

  1. Now the S/O order details are not being populated to Planned orders created from PIRs, therefore no planning inconsistancies.

Option 2: Activate “Assign effectivity parameter values/ override change numbers”

Turn off the Classic MRP check box

Now when planned using MRP live, material will be again planned under MRP live program, leading to planning inconsistancies.

Now activate Assign effect. vals

Although the purpose of Assign effect. Vals is different, but according to S/Note: 1914010, MRP Live on HANA does not support parameter effectivity. Therefore, by default, the materials will be planned by Classic MRP.

These are the two workarounds to force materials to be planned using Classic MRP.

Summary

1. Although, MRP live is a very powerful tool, it has it's own limitations (S/Note: 1914010), that can cause inconsistancies in planning. Therefore sometimes we need to force the material to plan in Classical MRP at the cost of MRP live advantages. 

2. To force material to plan in classic MRP, use T-code: MD_MRP_FORCE_CLASSIC, and check the classic MRP box.

3. If you consider, MD_MRP_FORCE_CLASSIC, as additional step, you can simply check the "Assign effect. Vals" in basic data 1 view of material master. Although it's puspose is different, it server the purpose in this case.

entry.title: Entendendo o Tipo de Item (Item Category) na Ordem de Venda – SAP SD
entry.content:
O que é um Tipo de Item (Item Category)?

O tipo de item determina o comportamento de cada linha da ordem de venda, incluindo:

 

  • Relevância para entrega e faturamento
  • Relevância para estoque (movimentação de mercadoria)
  • Relevância para preço
  • Permissão para entrada de quantidade zero ou valor zero
  • Se o item é apenas informativo ou comercial
  • Geração de requisição de transporte ou não

 

Ele é configurado no SPRO:

SAP IMG → Sales and Distribution → Sales → Sales Documents → Sales Document Item → Define Item Categories

Como o sistema determina o tipo de item?

O SAP usa a chave de determinação de tipo de item, baseada em três elementos:

  • Tipo de documento de venda (ex: OR)
  • Categoria de item do material (Item Category Group no material master)
  • Uso (Usage, opcional)
  • Alta/Baixa de estoque (Higher-level item category, se houver hierarquia)

 

Essa combinação é configurada via transação VOV4, e permite a determinação automática do tipo de item ao inserir o material na ordem.

 

Campos críticos na configuração (transação VOV7)

  • Billing relevance – determina se o item será faturado
  • Item relevant for delivery – indica se gera entrega
  • Pricing – se há cálculo de preço
  • Schedule line allowed – se o item permite cronogramas
  • Completion rule – como o item deve ser encerrado
  • Business data not copied – se dados da linha são independentes da linha pai

 

Impacto funcional do tipo de item

O tipo de item é decisivo para diversos processos integrados, como:

  • Pricing: Define se condições de preço são aplicáveis
  • Logística: Determina se gera entrega ou não
  • Contábil: Impacta no faturamento e contabilização
  • MRP: Pode disparar ou não planejamento de necessidades

O domínio da lógica de tipo de item é essencial para consultores funcionais SAP SD. Ele é a ponte entre o que o negócio quer vender e o que o sistema efetivamente executa.

Na dúvida? Analise o comportamento do item na VOV7 e a chave de determinação na VOV4, isso resolve 90% dos erros funcionais em ordens de venda.

E se você achou o conteúdo importante, deixe um comentário!

entry.title: Commitments in focus: How SAP S/4HANA is changing the management of financial commitments
entry.content:
What does commitment mean in the SAP context? 

Commitments describe the outstanding financial obligations of a company. These include, for example, orders, provisions or approved but not yet utilized funds. Although no payment has yet been made, these items impact liquidity, budgeting and risk assessment. 

SAP records such obligations in the system in several modules, in particular in Materials Management (MM), Financial Accounting (FI) and Controlling (CO). It is precisely at this interface that SAP S/4HANA’s decisive advantage emerges. 

GRAPHIC 1: Schematic overview of commitment processing between MM, FI and CO 

From static reporting to real-time insight 

SAP ECC already offered the option of managing commitments. However, the flow of information was often sluggish, fragmented and poorly integrated. Analyses were based on upstream reports that rarely reflected the current data situation. 

SAP S/4HANA solves this problem with real-time data processing. Every relevant transaction, be it an order, an investment application or a provision, is immediately recorded in the system and can be analyzed instantly. The underlying SAP HANA database ensures that data is not only quickly available but also intelligently linked. 

Comparison of COOI and ACDOCA: the evolution of commitment management 

A key difference between SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA lies in how financial obligations are managed and mapped. In SAP ECC, the COOI table (open orders, accruals and commitments) played a central role in commitment management. This table recorded open items and provided an overview of financial obligations but was often static and limited in terms of updates. 

With SAP S/4HANA, commitments are managed via the ACDOCA table. This central financial accounting table offers several advantages: 

  1. Real-time data processing:
    ACDOCA enables the recording and evaluation of transactions in real time. This means that every change is immediately reflected in the system, resulting in an up-to-date and accurate representation of financial obligations.      
  2. Integrated data structure:
    In contrast to the fragmented data management in ECC, ACDOCA integrates data from different modules and processes, providing a more comprehensive overview of financial obligations and their impact on the organization. 
  3. Extended analysis functions:
    With the ACDOCA data, organizations can perform complex analyses, such as plan/actual comparisons and trend analysis, which were previously difficult to carry out. This enables targeted management of the financial strategy and early identification of potential risks.     
  4. Flexibility and adaptability:
    ACDOCA's modern data structure supports easy adaptation to increasing requirements and the integration of new technologies such as AI-supported analyses and forecasts.     

This transition from COOI to ACDOCA clearly illustrates how SAP S/4HANA has advanced commitment management and supports companies in not only recording financial commitments, but also actively managing and strategically utilizing them. 

 GRAPHIC 2: Comparison of the commitment functionality in SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA 

 

Advantages of real-time data processing in SAP S/4HANA: 

  1. Application example - supply chain management:
    A company uses SAP S/4HANA to monitor its stock levels in real time. By recording orders and deliveries immediately, it can react more quickly to changes in demand and avoid bottlenecks. This leads to more efficient warehousing and reduced storage costs.
  2. Case study - Financial planning:
    A company in the energy sector implements SAP S/4HANA to gain real-time insight into its financial obligations. By immediately recording investment requests and provisions, the company can plan its liquidity more accurately and identify financial risks at an early stage. This leads to improved strategic decision-making and optimized budget management.     
  3.  

A new level of integration and analysis 

Another milestone is the seamless integration. SAP S/4HANA not only links MM, FI and CO technically, but also creates a unified view of obligations. This means that not only individual items, but also comprehensive budget evaluations or plan-versus-actual comparisons are possible at the touch of a button. 

At the same time, modern analytics functions offer new insights. Companies can recognize trends, identify anomalies at an early stage and make decisions based on reliable figures. 

Explanation of the Fiori interface and its advantages: 

The SAP Fiori interface offers a modern, intuitive and responsive design that greatly simplifies access to SAP applications. Users benefit from a role-based user experience that takes their specific tasks and needs into account. This enables a personalized and efficient way of working, as users can quickly access the information and functions relevant to their role without having to navigate through complex menus and transactions. The Fiori interface is particularly beneficial for users without in-depth technical system knowledge, as it facilitates the use of SAP applications and increases productivity through clear visualizations and simple interactions.  

GRAPHIC 3: SAP Fiori dashboard with current commitment values 

 

Exposure in the project business: actively managing cash flow 

Commitments have a particularly strategic impact in the project environment. SAP S/4HANA makes it possible to update payment obligations assigned to WBS elements, networks and orders, automatically and with precise value types. This creates the basis for project-related liquidity planning based on actual obligations. 

Down payments, allocations and project-related target/actual comparisons can also be clearly mapped. The ability to adjust financial items as required also increases flexibility. 

GRAPHIC 4: Project-oriented commitment process from the WBS element to the commitment 

Concrete implementation and specific functions of SAP S/4HANA 

User-friendliness thanks to the Fiori interface  

A key difference in the implementation of commitment management between SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA lies in the use of the modern Fiori interface, which enables more intuitive and user-friendly interaction. This interface supports a role-based and personalized user experience, allowing users to work efficiently without in-depth system knowledge. 

Use of intelligent functions for commitment management  

In addition, SAP S/4HANA offers specific functions such as AI-supported forecasting models that help to better manage future obligations and identify risks at an early stage. These models use historical data and probabilities to provide automated decision-making tools that significantly simplify commitment management. 

Technical implementation with CDS views and virtual data model 

In order to make optimum use of the functions and forecasting models mentioned, a robust database is required. The available CDS views in particular play a central role in analyzing the commitments. The content provides a manageable selection of CDS views that can be used to analyze the obligations. In the project context, it is advisable to check the associated virtual data model (VDM) and the definition of the key figures to see whether they reflect the requirements of the specialist area. This may result in expansion requirements that need to be mapped in the customer's own CDS views. In particular, when combining data from the two tables COOI and ACDOCA, it must be checked how these are merged. 

What's next? A look at the roadmap 

The development of SAP S/4HANA is far from complete. The upcoming releases promise, among other things, AI-supported forecasting models for commitment management. Automated decision-making aids based on historical data and probabilities will further reduce the burden on day-to-day business. 

A lot is also happening in terms of user-friendliness. The continuous improvement of the Fiori apps ensures that both controllers and project managers can work efficiently with commitments without in-depth system knowledge. 

Conclusion: Managing commitments, not just recording them 

Commitments not only show what a company has already incurred. They are a mirror of future expenditure and therefore an early warning system for the company's finances. SAP S/4HANA takes this tool to a new level by combining real-time data, integrated processes and dynamic analysis functions with modern implementation approaches and specific functions. With the Fiori interface and AI-supported forecasting models, commitments is transformed from a mere booking value into a strategic management tool. Companies that rely on these new possibilities can monitor commitments more specifically, manage budgets more precisely and identify financial risks earlier. The key to this lies in the intelligent use of existing data and a system that makes this data available in real time and in a user-friendly way. 

But that's just our view. How does your company perceive these changes? What experiences have you had with the implementation and use of SAP S/4HANA in commitment management? We look forward to hearing your perspectives and discussing new solutions together.

entry.title: SAP Clean Core + BTP = Future-Ready ERP: Streamline Upgrades and Accelerate AI Adoption
entry.content:
In the rapidly evolving enterprise landscape, maintaining agility while preserving system integrity is critical. SAP has introduced the Clean Core concept to address this need — a strategic approach that encourages minimal customizations to the core SAP ERP system, while shifting extensions and innovations to cloud-native platforms like SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). This not only simplifies system upgrades and lowers technical debt but also enhances long-term scalability and innovation potential.

What is SAP Clean Core?

SAP Clean Core refers to the principle of keeping the core SAP ERP system as close to standard as possible. It encourages:

  • Avoiding intrusive custom code directly within the ERP core.
  • Using side-by-side extensibility for custom functionalities.
  • Adopting SAP-approved frameworks and tools for integration and extension.

Mainly, it ensures that customers can utilize out-of-the-box functionality. It facilitates easier integration of AI and other emerging technologies.

How BTP Helps Mitigate Clean Core Challenges

SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) plays a central role in enabling a clean core by offering services and tools that support side-by-side extensions. Here's how BTP mitigates clean core challenges:

  • Application Development & Integration: BTP provides environments (e.g., SAP Build, CAP, RAP, Kyma) to develop and deploy custom apps without touching the ERP core.
  • Event-Driven Architecture: Through SAP Event Mesh or SAP Integration Suite, events from ERP can trigger actions on BTP for loosely coupled integrations.
  • Low-code/No-code Tools: Business users can innovate quickly using SAP Build Apps and Process Automation, bypassing core modifications.
  • Data & Analytics: With SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Analytics Cloud, businesses can build advanced analytics models and dashboards independent of the core.
  • Security and Governance: Centralized identity management and audit services ensure compliance without overloading ERP layers.

By decoupling custom logic and innovations from the ERP core, BTP ensures faster deployments and safer upgrades.

In essence, a clean core approach clears out the complexities and legacy issues that can hinder the adoption of AI, providing a stable, standardized, and agile foundation upon which an organization can build intelligent, AI-powered solutions.

entry.title: Accelerate Your SAP S/4HANA Journey with Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE)
entry.content:
Accelerate Your SAP S/4HANA Journey with Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE)

This article is the first in a series exploring Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE). In upcoming article, we will dive into methodology, scenario selection, tooling, and more to demystify SDTE and showcase its value.

Modern enterprises are under constant pressure to innovate and optimize. For those running on SAP ERP, transitioning to SAP S/4HANA is a significant milestone - but how can you preserve your past investments that give you a competitive edge while embracing the latest technology and use the chance to optimize processes? SAP S/4HANA Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE) is specifically designed to address this challenge. By retaining what sets you apart, and standardizing areas where it makes sense, SDTE offers a flexible, efficient path to transformation.

 

Business Challenge

Balancing Differentiation and Standardization

Enterprises running SAP ERP have often spent years - or even decades - developing custom processes, industry-specific extensions, and unique reporting. These innovations are competitive differentiators that users rely on every day. At the same time, core "commodity" processes (Finance, Procurement, Manufacturing, HR) can gain dramatically from standardized best practices baked into SAP S/4HANA. The fundamental tension: How do you preserve what sets you apart while embracing the efficiency and innovation that come with a modern digital core?

Reducing IT Burden and TCO

Maintaining multiple legacy systems - each with its own data archives - drives up infrastructure costs, complicates backups and restores, and hampers analytics. As organizations plan moves to cloud offerings like RISE with SAP, every gigabyte contributes to ongoing subscription and storage expenses. Selective data transition helps by consolidating landscapes, cleansing aged records, and migrating only what truly matters - slashing total cost of ownership (TCO).

Ensuring Business Continuity

Prolonged downtime windows and sprawling, multi-year pre-projects erode user confidence and delay the realization of business benefits. CIOs, CFOs, enterprise architects, and process owners all share one goal: modernize without bringing the business to a halt. An effective migration strategy must keep business impact to a bare minimum while delivering a future-proof digital core.

 

The SDTE Solution - A Flexible, Targeted Approach

Unlike a one-size-fits-all implementation or a straightforward system conversion, SDTE offers a customer-specific roadmap:

  • Selectively Retain Data that remains relevant for analysis or compliance, while discarding obsolete or low-value data.
  • Incorporate Process Harmonization right away, without needing to spin off separate, time-consuming pre-projects.
  • Preservation of Custom Differentiators Carry forward the custom processes and extensions that users depend on, while standardizing commodity processes to leverage SAP S/4HANA best practices.
  • Adopt Modern, Standardized Practices for commodity processes, speeding up efficiency gains in finance, supply chain, and beyond.

Reduce System Footprint for the Cloud

When you move to the cloud, every gigabyte matters. By migrating only the relevant data, you can effectively reduce system footprint, cut storage costs, and ensure you don't drag inefficiencies into your new SAP S/4HANA landscape. At the same time, you'll feed AI-driven scenarios with the best, most accurate historical data - enabling predictive maintenance, more refined demand planning, or improved financial forecasting.

Consolidate Landscapes and Unlock Value

SDTE also excels at landscape consolidation - merging multiple ERP systems into a single SAP S/4HANA instance. This not only simplifies ongoing maintenance and upgrades but also improves transparency for reporting and analytics. Companies that take advantage of this flexibility experience significant cost savings and faster ROI.

Faster Time-to-Value

A hallmark of SDTE is its ability to eliminate or shorten many pre-projects, such as separately addressing finance harmonization or data cleansing. Because these transformations can be integrated into the main migration event, your organization realizes business benefits more quickly - with less effort from end users and fewer touchpoints for potential disruption.

 

Technical Detail

How Does the Engagement Work?

SDTE projects build on SAP Activate, enriched with SDTE-specific checkpoints:

  1. Discover
    Your business processes, data volumes, and future vision are analyzed to see what exactly needs to be transformed or left behind.
  2. Prepare
    A targeted plan is set up, detailing which data to migrate or cleanse. Tools and technical environments are installed to enable secure, high-performance data transfers.
  3. Explore and Realize
    Agile iterations test the migration rules, verifying that the relevant data is selected and transformed. Customizations are preserved where necessary, and processes are standardized where they are beneficial.
  4. Deploy/Run
    With SDTE variety of data migration approaches including minimized downtime approaches, your move to SAP S/4HANA can be scheduled over a weekend or other minimal business-impact window. Rigorous testing ensures everything functions smoothly.
  5. Quality Gates
    Throughout these phases, SDTE methodology includes checkpoints to maintain high standards, reduce risk, and ensure you are on track.

 

Tools, Principles, and Best Practices

  • Flexible Migration Approach: SDTE supports multiple different migration approaches like posting and table based. By default high-speed data transfer that bypasses application-level constraints, letting you harmonize or map data according to your new structures and preserve historical data.
  • Integration of Cleansing and Enrichment: Legacy data can be enriched, ensuring that your new system fuels modern capabilities like AI and advanced analytics.
  • System Landscape Consolidation: SDTE partners bring proven methods to merge or split SAP systems, helping you standardize reporting, unify master data, and gain complete transparency.

 

Success Stories

Pharmaceutical Company (Global): Data Footprint Reduction and Faster Time-to-Value

Customer consolidated an 85 TB ECC environment into a streamlined S/4HANA landscape, selectively retaining five years of history (down from 27) and migrating just 427 of 1,100 company codes. By combining landscape consolidation, selective retention, and finance harmonization in a single project, the customer accelerated value delivery and minimized disruption.

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Landscape Consolidation: Multiple organizational units merged into one unified system.
  • Data Footprint Reduction: Historical data pruned by 80%, shrinking the HANA footprint.
  • Faster Time-to-Value: Combined disparate initiatives into one go-live event.

Chemicals Company (Japan): Phase approach and Full migration of historical data

The transition to the new system required migrating full historical data, including data archives from the SAP ERP application to SAP S/4HANA to realize data continuity for a set of company codes. Furthermore, the customer had to plan for and then execute various data conversions and codification changes in its general ledger accounts, materials numbers, profit centers, and so on to meet the data management requirements of the new system

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Selective Data Retention: Only a set of company codes moved, legacy archives remained untouched.
  • Phased approach: Project split in multiple phases allowing flexibility and reducing the impact on the customer team,
  • Process Harmonization: various data conversions in general ledger accounts, materials numbers, profit centers to meet the data management requirements of the new system

 

Vision: The Future of Data Migration and Beyond

AI-Driven Efficiency

As artificial intelligence evolves, expect even more automation of data mapping, cleansing, and harmonization. AI can swiftly identify inconsistencies, propose corrective actions, and optimize transformations - lowering manual effort and reducing errors.

Standardization at Scale

With AI and continuous improvement, standards for data migration become more universal, making it easier to share best practices and lessons learned. This streamlines future transformations while reducing costs and risks.

Addressing the Resource Shortage

IT transformation skills are scarce, but AI-driven acceleration can help bridge the gap. Automated rule generation and scenario testing mean teams can get more done with fewer specialized resources.

As a result, IT can shift from a cost center to a genuine business enabler - fueling innovation rather than being bogged down by legacy systems.

 

Call to Action

You have seen how SDTE preserves your unique differentiators, modernizes core processes, and accelerates your move to a lean, cloud-ready SAP S/4HANA environment - while laying the foundation for AI-powered operational excellence.

Next in our series: As SDT encompasses a variety of pathways rather than a single one, our upcoming article will explore SDT Scenario Selection, focusing on:

  • SDT Scenarios Overview: Discussing the best practice SDT scenarios that are available and commonly used in projects.
  • Key Decision Drivers: Identifying the factors that influence the selection of the optimal SDT scenario for your transformation

In the meantime:

  1. Explore Webinars and Resources
    Discover more about SDTE via official SAP Support Portal webinars or community sessions that dive deeper into the specifics.
  2. Contact the SDTE Community
    Reach out to the expert group of SAP and its partners for an assessment of your current landscape. They can help identify how selective data transition can best fit your needs.
  3. Start Your Transformation
    Do not wait until maintenance windows close or all experts are not available anymore. A well-planned selective data migration can future-proof your IT environment and jump-start your intelligent enterprise journey.

Take the next step by visiting
SDTE Engagement Overview
to connect with the SDTE community and chart out your custom path to SAP S/4HANA success.

entry.title: Empowering Business Users with Personalized News in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release
entry.content:
Keeping business users informed about system and company news is essential for organizational success. When users are aware of changes that could impact their daily tasks, they can make better decisions, adapt more quickly, and boost overall productivity. Staying up to date—especially with updates on processes, departments, or system changes—helps eliminate confusion and ensures alignment across teams.  

While our existing news feed provides valuable updates on SAP system changes, we’ve listened closely to customer feedback and enhanced communication and user experience on My Home even further. In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, we now offer the ability to customize and manage the My Home news feed through the new Manage News application.

Manage News Application

 

Introducing the Manage News Application 

The Manage News application empowers news administrators to deliver timely, targeted information updates directly to business users via a centralized news feed. 

Key capabilities for news administrators include: 

  • Create, manage, and publish news articles: Administrators can compose news posts to be displayed on My Home, controlling the flow of critical company and system updates. 
  • Control visibility and importance: News items can be marked as critical, ensuring essential information is highlighted and receives appropriate attention from business users. 
  • Plan and schedule communications: Administrators can organize when specific news should be published, enabling timely and organized delivery of updates. 
  • Language adaptation: Messages can be tailored in all company-supported languages, ensuring effective communication across diverse user groups. 
  • Targeted audience assignment: News can be assigned to specific App Transaction codes, so only users with access to the corresponding Fiori apps or transaction codes will see relevant news items. 
  • Organize news by groups or categories: News articles can be grouped into categories such as Finance or Human Resources, making it easy for users to find pertinent information. 
  • Visual enhancements: Administrators can upload images aligned with news topics to make posts more engaging and visually informative. 

News article creation in Manage News Application

 

What Business Users Will Experience 

The My Home news feed now displays articles created by news administrators, neatly organized into designated categories. Critical updates are clearly marked with an eye-catching critical marker to ensure users notice and prioritize these messages. 

This personalized news feature centralizes essential communications in one place, tailored to the needs of each user based on their system app access. By delivering relevant, timely information directly to business users, organizations can foster a more informed and agile workforce. 

 Critical News displayed in My Home News Feed 

Critical News Article in My Home News dialog

 

Benefits for Your Organization 

With the Manage News application, administrators can tailor the news feed to reflect the specific needs of your company or organization, enabling more effective communication with business users. This streamlined and targeted approach to information sharing helps: 

  • Improve user awareness and decision-making 
  • Minimize confusion and misalignment across teams 
  • Increase adaptability to system or process changes 
  • Enhance overall company performance 

 

Prerequisites 

To access the Manage News application users or administrators will have to be assigned to the SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_MNG_PC business catalogue. For business users to view the news feed on My Home they will have to be assigned SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_DSP_PC catalogue. The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE role will already have SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_DSP_PC business catalogue assigned. With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, news maintained in the Manage News application will be displayed by default for all customers who have not configured a RSS feed or SAP Custom System News. To display the news from the Manage News application the 'Manage News App' setting needs to be enabled via UI Adaptation mode (Adapt UI in the User Actions menu). Users or administrator must have the catalog SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_FLEX attached to their role to access the UI Adaptation key user capabilities. 

My Home UI Adaptation Mode News Feed Settings

 

We’re excited to bring this powerful new communication feature to you with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release and look forward to seeing how it helps your business stay connected and informed.

entry.title: Currency and unit conversion in SAP Datasphere Analytic Model with variable and value help
entry.content:
Currency conversion is the act of changing financial information from one currency into another. This process is especially crucial for global businesses that conduct operations across various countries and handle transactions in multiple currencies.

Unit conversion is also important because it ensures consistency, accuracy, and clarity when working with different measurement systems. Unit conversion enables accurate, effective communication and operations across systems, industries, and borders.

The following steps are carried out for currency / unit conversion in SAP Datasphere:

1. Create currency / unit conversion tables and views

2. Create a task chain and schedule it

3. Determine the semantic type and the associated unit in the fact view

4. Create input parameters with input help

5. Add conversion measure in analytical model

For currency conversion these tables must be available in your SAP S/4 HANA system:

  • TCURV - Exchange rate types
  • TCURW - Exchange rate type text
  • TCURX - Decimal places in currencies
  • TCURN - Quotations
  • TCURR - Exchange rates
  • TCURF - Conversion factors
  • TCURC - Currency codes
  • TCURT - Currency text

For unit conversion these tables must be available in your SAP S/4 HANA system:

  • T006 - Units of Measurement
  • T006D - Dimensions
  • T006A - Assign Internal to Language-Dependent Unit

    1. Create currency / unit conversion tables and views

a) Start the creation of the corresponding tables and views in the correct space in the Data Builder via Create and Currency / Unit Conversion Views

b) Choose source system and check objects. 

c) After clicking on “Create”, all objects are created automatically.

2. Create a task chain and schedule it

Create a task chain and include all relevant data flows to upload data into the required tables. To keep the data up to date, it is advisable to schedule the task chain.

3. Determine the semantic type and the associated unit in the fact view

In the fact view, which is located under the analytical model, you must maintain the semantic types of the key figures and the associated units. Conversion in the analytical model can only take place through this step.

4. Create input parameters with input help

If the user is to be provided with a value aid when calling up variables, one or more input parameters must be created in the fact view.

If you only want to provide users with a narrow list with a few units, you can build a view on the unit table and enter it here as value help. You can also set a default value here.

Attention: You may have to set the field length of WAERS to 3 in the view.

5. Add conversion measure in analytical model

a) You can now create conversion measures in the analytical model.

b) Enter business name and technical name for your new measure. Select source measure. SAP Datasphere uses the source key figure to recognize whether a unit or currency conversion needs to be carried out.

c) Select the date to which you want to convert and the appropriate exchange rate type (only for currency translation). Then click on the selection help for Target Currency and select “Variable”.

Click on "Use existing Source Variable" and choose the correct one.

d) Under “Advanced”, select the client that is maintained in the TCURR table and what should happen if an error occurs.

TCURR:

e) Go back to main Analytic Model Properties and check error messages or test the new measure in preview.

Tip:

If the analytical model existed before the input parameters were created in the fact view below, they must be mapped manually to new or existing variables.

 

Conclusion

Currency and unit conversions are foundational components in ensuring data integrity, consistency, and meaningful analysis in multinational environments. SAP Datasphere offers a structured and streamlined approach to managing these conversions by leveraging integrated tables from SAP S/4HANA and guided steps within the Data Builder and analytical model.

By systematically creating conversion views, automating data flows through task chains, assigning semantic types, configuring input parameters, and defining conversion measures, users can implement robust, scalable conversion logic. This ensures that financial and operational data across diverse units and currencies are harmonized and ready for accurate reporting and decision-making.
